data.name: WhatsNewFormContent
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fswiss\fprq2 Calibri;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue255;} {\*\generator Riched20 10.0.17763}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\b\f0\fs20 The most recent version of i-Tree Eco offers several upgrades over previous version, including the following:\par \b0\par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\sl276\slmult1\b\f1 New Global Locations\f0 \b0 -\f1 The i-Tree User community has provided data through i-Tree Database to facilitate integration of numerous international cities throughout Europe, Asia, and Latin America for automated processing in Eco. Search your project location in the i-Tree Database by providing information \f0 on {{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK https://database.itreetools.org/#/viableLocations }}{\fldrslt{https://database.itreetools.org/#/viableLocations\ul0\cf0}}}}\f0\fs20\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}\b\f1 New Reports\b0 \f0 -\f1 You can now view and download estimates for air pollution removal due to energy effects of individual trees. To access this report go to Reports > Individual Level Results > Energy Avoided Pollutants.\f0\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}\b 2016 Weather and Pollution Data now included.\f1 \b0\f0\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}\b Weather data now included for 2017 and 2018 - \b0 When pollution data becomes available for 2017 and 2018 that will be incorporated.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}\b U.S. Carbon and CO\sub 2\nosupersub dollar valuations \b0 have been updated to:\par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\sl276\slmult1\ul Carbon\ulnone price per 1 metric ton is $188.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}\ul CO\sub 2\ulnone\nosupersub equivalent price per 1 metric ton is $188/3.67 or approximately $51.22.\par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li1080\sl276\slmult1 These values are taken from the Social Cost of Carbon ({{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2016-12/documents/sc_co2_tsd_august_2016.pdf }}{\fldrslt{https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2016-12/documents/sc_co2_tsd_august_2016.pdf\ul0\cf0}}}}\f0\fs20 ) and are adjusted to 2018 dollars.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Eco previously used $145.95 per metric ton of carbon.\par
\pard\sl276\slmult1\par
\pard\widctlpar\b To see all the recent changes made to i-Tree Eco, please review the change log, located under the Support tab.\b0\par } �

data.name: UVEffectsByStrataReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;\red0\green0\blue255;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > UV Effects of Trees > By Strata\par \b0\par \pard\brdrt\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of the effects that trees have on the ultraviolet (UV) radiation received in your study area. UV radiation is emitted by the sun and while beneficial to humans in small doses, can have negative health effects when people are overexposed. The UV index scale was developed by the World Health Organization to more easily communicate daily levels of UV radiation and alert people to when protection from overexposure is needed most. UV index values are estimated from UV radiation and adjusted based on local elevation and cloud cover.\par \par Tree canopies help to reduce the amount of UV radiation that reaches the ground thus providing people with additional protection from the sun\rquote s harmful rays. UV effects are reported in this table for each stratum and the study area as a whole and broken into the following results:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 UV Effects in Tree Shade \endash changes in UV for a person who is always shaded by tree canopy. For example, someone who is sitting under a tree.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}UV Effects Overall \endash changes in UV for a person who is in both areas that are shaded by tree canopy and areas that are not. For example, someone who is walking down a street may find themselves under tree canopy at some times and exposed to full UV radiation at others.\par \pard\fi-360\li720\b\par \pard\b0 Results are additionally reported for the following:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Protection factor \endash a unitless value meant to capture the UV radiation-blocking capacity of trees. It is comparable to the SPF rating in sunscreen and calculated as unshaded UV index divided by shaded or overall UV index.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Reduction in UV Index \endash the change in UV index as the result of trees and calculated as unshaded UV index minus shaded or overall UV index.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Percent reduction \endash the reduction in UV index expressed as a percent change and calculated as the reduction in UV index divided by unshaded UV index.\par \pard\b\par Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 For more information on the UV index scale, visit {\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "http://www.who.int/uv/intersunprogramme/activities/uv_index/en/"}}{\fldrslt{\ul\cf2 http://www.who.int/uv/intersunprogramme/activities/uv_index/en/}}}\f0\fs20\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: ForecastConfigurations
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Configurations\par \pard\b0\par The \b Configurations\b0 group in the ribbon above is important for managing your Forecast parameters. One of the useful features of Forecast is that you can make use of the component many different ways by projecting future estimates with any number of combinations of settings, tree planting scenarios, and extreme events. Each one of these combinations is a different configuration and can be defined by going through the Basic or Custom Options of the ribbon. You can also choose to run Forecast without providing any special information and simply using the defaults provided.\par \par The \b Active Configuration\b0 drop-down list is where you select which configuration you would like to work with. You will see all of the parameters (i.e., mortality options, tree planting scenarios, and extreme events) that you defined in the functions of the action panel. Please note that the configuration that is selected here will define the settings for your results when you run Forecast. Always check which configuration is selected before running Forecast.\par \par The \b Rename\b0 , \b New\b0 , \b Duplicate\b0 , and \b Delete\b0 tools allow you to rename the active configuration, create a new configuration, duplicate the active configuration, or delete the active configuration.\par \par The \b Restore Defaults\b0 function will reset all parameters (i.e., mortality options, tree planting scenarios, and extreme events) that you have set for the active configuration back to the default values.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: DiebacksForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Project Configuration > Define Data Fields > Crown Health\par \pard\par \b0 The \b Dieback \b0 field seen in the action panel to the right describes tree crown health as estimated during data collection. Crown health is based on a visual assessment of the amount of dead branches (i.e., dieback) in the crown. To record dieback, users will collect the percent of the crown that is composed of dead branches. i-Tree Eco includes 22 default dieback classes. \par \par Users may choose to record crown health as condition instead of dieback. To change how you would like to record crown health, go to \b Project Definition\b0 > \b Data Collection Options\b0 .\par \par \b *IMPORTANT*\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 We highly recommend that users creating a new Eco project use the default dieback classes. Working with the default classes fosters more precise data collection in the field and standardization in reporting.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}For users importing tree data from a spreadsheet, customizing these classes will be necessary if the tree data does not follow the default classes.\par \pard\par \b Steps to Customize:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When \b Editing Mode\b0 is \b On\b0 , the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of dieback classes.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create or delete classes, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}In the \ldblquote Description\rdblquote column, enter your dieback class. This can be in number, range, or text format.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}In the \ldblquote % Dieback\rdblquote\b \b0 column, enter the percent that corresponds to the dieback class. For example, the defaults provided include a 5%-10% (good) dieback class for which the midpoint of that range, 8, is entered in \ldblquote % Dieback.\rdblquote \par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}To make text changes, click in the desired box on the table.\par \pard\b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 The classes that are displayed here will be available on a mobile data collector, as well as in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon. \par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\qj Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the data table here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ForecastBasicForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Forecast > Basic Options\par \pard\b0\par The \b Basic Options\b0 function seen in the action panel to the right can be used to customize your Forecast results at a very basic level. \par \par Please note that making changes here is \ul optional\ulnone . If you would like to use the i-Tree Eco defaults, do not make changes in this action panel (see Notes below).\par \par If you decide that you would like to customize your project, you can change any of the following variables:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\sa200\b Duration of the forecast (years) \b0\endash i-Tree Eco default is 30 years. This variable is used to determine how many years into the future your results will be forecasted. For example, if you choose to use the default, the Forecast component will estimate the structure and function of the urban forest in your study area every year for the next 30 years (see Notes below).\par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Days of the year without frost (days) \b0\endash i-Tree Eco default is 150 days. This variable is used to determine the growing season of your study area, which adjusts growth in tree DBH (diameter at breast height) over time.\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b Base annual mortality rates (%) \b0\endash The values presented here show the default annual mortality rates for healthy trees with 0-49% dieback (3.0% annual mortality), sick trees with 50-74% dieback (13.1% annual mortality), and dying trees with 75-99% dieback (50.0% annual mortality). You may change the base mortality rates for each of these condition classes. The rate that you provide indicates the percent of trees in that condition class that will die each year. For healthy trees, this mortality rate is an average starting rate that is adjusted up or down depending on the tree DBH class.\par \pard\par \b Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 To change the duration of the forecast, either type the number of years directly in the box provided or use the up and down arrows on your keyboard to increase or decrease the number.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}To change the days of the year without frost, either type the number of days directly in the box provided or use the up and down arrows to increase or decrease the number.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}To change mortality rates, either type the rate directly in the box provided or use the up and down arrows to increase or decrease the number.\par \pard\b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you do choose to make changes in the \b Basic Options\b0 function, the changes you make can be reset to the defaults by clicking on the \b Restore Defaults\b0 button of the \b Configurations\b0 group. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}The Forecast component of i-Tree Eco estimates the future structure and function of your urban forest by incorporating anticipated growth and mortality rates. This provides you with an estimate of what your urban forest will look like in the future. You can even include future tree planting scenarios or possible adverse events, such as a storm or pest infestation, to predict their impact on your urban forest.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: LeafAreaBiomassTreeShrubStrataReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Leaf Area and Biomass > Of Trees and Shrubs by Strata\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides per area (density) and total estimates of leaf area and leaf biomass for tree and shrub species by strata. Per area estimates are calculated by dividing the total leaf area or total leaf biomass of each species by the area of the stratum. Results include estimates of standard error.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: InventoryTreesForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue255;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20 Data > Inventory Data > Trees\par \pard\tx720\b0 February 2022\~\fs22\par \fs20\~\fs22\par \b\fs20 The Eco species list has been updated to remove synonyms and cultivars\~\b0\fs22\par \b\fs20\~\b0\fs22\par \fs20 If there are species in this project that are no longer on the Eco species list there will be exclamation symbols indicating those cells. To correct the unmatched species, click on the Check Data button at the top of the window. \~\fs22\par \fs20\~\fs22\par \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\lang9\fs20 For more information concerning this change go here: {\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "https://forums.itreetools.org/viewtopic.php?f=19&t=6486"}}{\fldrslt{\ul\cf1 https://forums.itreetools.org/viewtopic.php?f=19&t=6486}}}\lang1033\f0\fs22\par \pard\fs20 The \b Trees\b0 table seen in the action panel to the right displays the tree data that you collected in the field (see Notes below). This is where you will enter your tree data manually or edit your previously added or imported data. While working in this table, you may use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to help manually enter new data or edit data that has already been added.\par \pard\tx720\par \b Steps to Manually Add/Edit Data:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Click in the box where you would like to enter data and begin typing.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the Tab key on your keyboard or the left and right arrows to move from side to side within a record.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the up and down arrows on the keyboard to move from top to bottom between records.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}For boxes that contain drop-down lists, you can choose your data from the list or begin typing and the matching label will be automatically filled in.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}For boxes where dates are entered, a calendar pop-up will appear if you click on the calendar icon in the right-hand side of the cell. Select the date from the calendar. Click the header at the top of the pop-up to see other available months. Click the header again to see additional available years. \par \pard\li360\tx360\tx720\par \pard\tx720\b Steps for Using Actions Tools:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When you click on the \b Trees\b0 function, the \b Actions\b0 group will become available in the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the \b New \b0 tool to create a new record in the tree table.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the \b Delete\b0 tool to remove the selected record(s) from the table.\par \pard\tx720\par \pard\b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 Taxonomic classes (i.e., Magnoliopsida, Pinopsida, Ginkgoopsida, Liliopsida, Filicopsida, Cycadopsida) should be used sparingly when identifying the species of live trees. These classes can be used to represent the more generic classifications. However, species data is important to the calculation of ecosystem services \endash more specific species identification provides better model estimates.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}If you have imported your data from the mobile data collector using the \b Retrieve from Mobile\b0 function of the \b Data\b0 tab, you will see all of the imported field data for your project here. \par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}If you opened a project or are working with data that was previously entered, you will see all of the field data for your project here.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Some data fields are defined on the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab. If you do not see the options you want from the drop-down list for a certain data field, you will need to go back to the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab to edit the list of options for that data field.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the tree data here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}If you recorded the GPS coordinates (latitude and longitude) of each tree during field data collection, you will be able to make use of Eco's \b KML\b0 function. Use the \b KML\b0 function in the ribbon to export the tree data here to a "keyhole markup language" (kml) file. Data exported as a kml file are compatible with software programs that include Google Earth and ArcGIS and allow you to view tree locations spatially.\par \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\par Use this workbook, {\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "https://www.itreetools.org/documents/736/Synonym_Lookup_Form.xlsx"}}{\fldrslt{\ul\cf1 https://www.itreetools.org/documents/736/Synonym_Lookup_Form.xlsx}}}\f0\fs20 , to lookup the scientific and common names i-Tree recognizes.\lang9\par \i For more information: \i0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "https://www.itreetools.org/support/resources-overview/i-tree-manuals-workbooks"}}{\fldrslt{\ul\cf1 https://www.itreetools.org/support/resources-overview/i-tree-manuals-workbooks}}}\f0\fs22\par \pard\sa160\sl252\slmult1\lang1033\par \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\lang9\f1\par } �

data.name: ForecastByStrataTreeBiomassReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Forecast > Reports > Composition and Structure > Leaf Area and Biomass > Tree Biomass by Strata\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the total tree biomass of the trees in your study area estimated for each year in the future. The total tree biomass in Year 0 is based on the current tree biomass in your study area from the structural estimates provided by Eco. Results are presented for each stratum in your study area.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration tab or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: TranspirationTreeReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Reports > Charts > Pollution and Weather > Transpiration > By Trees\b0\par \pard\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the hourly transpiration by trees. Transpiration is the amount of water moved through plants and released to the atmosphere. This report displays results in line chart and table formats for the user-designated weather year.\par \par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: DefinePlotsFileForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Project Configuration > Define Plots > Load from File\par \pard\par \b0 If you are conducting a plot-based sample, you need to define the plots where you will be collecting your data. The \b Load\b0 \b from\b0 \b File\b0 function seen in the action panel to the right is one of the methods for defining your plots. This option allows you to create a sample of plots using ArcGIS, and then import the plot list into i-Tree Eco.\par \par \b Steps:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360 Click on the \b Browse\b0 button next to the \b Plot\b0 \b List\b0 \b File\b0 box.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Navigate to the plot list file that you previously created and click \b Open\b0 . (Note: This file must be in txt format.)\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Click on the \b Browse\b0 button next to the \b Strata\b0 \b File\b0 box.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Navigate to the strata file that you previously created and click \b Open\b0 . (Note: This file must be in txt format.)\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Click on the \b Browse\b0 button next to the \b GIS\b0 \b Projection\b0 \b File\b0 box.\par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}Navigate to the GIS projection file that you previously created and click \b Open\b0 . (Note: This file must be in prj format.)\par {\pntext\f0 7.\tab}Click \b Import\b0 .\par \pard\par For more information on how to set up a plot file to load here, please see the user guide to \b Pre-stratified Samples\b0 ,\b Post-stratified Samples\b0 , or \b Unstratified Samples \b0 (depending on your project goals) available under \b User Guides \b0 in the \b Support\b0 tab.\b\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\par } �

data.name: PollutantFluxGrassReport
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Reports > Charts > Pollution and Weather > Air Pollutant Flux (Dry Deposition) > Per Unit Grass/Herbaceous Cover\b0\par
\pard\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the hourly dry deposition of air pollutants per unit of grass/herbaceous cover. This report displays results in line chart and table formats for the user-designated pollution year. Estimates are reported for the following pollutants:\par \par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Nitrogen dioxide (NO\sub 2\nosupersub )\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Sulfur dioxide (SO\sub 2\nosupersub )\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Ozone (O\sub 3\nosupersub )\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Carbon monoxide (CO)\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Particulate matter less than 2.5 microns (PM\sub 2.5\nosupersub )\par
\pard\par \b Steps:\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Choose the pollutant that you would like to view by selecting it from the drop-down list at the top of the action panel.\par
\pard\par \b Notes:\par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 The reports for grass/herbaceous cover will be available only when the location is in 48 US continental states and ground cover information is collected.\b\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par
\pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\f1\fs22\lang9\par } �

data.name: TreeConditionByStratumAndSpeciesCustom
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Crown Health > By Stratum and Species\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of the percent of each tree species by stratum found in each crown health class as defined under Data > Report Classes > Crown Health.\par \par Crown Health is based on either Condition or Dieback as chosen during project setup in the the Project Configuration > Project Definition > Data Collection Options window.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: NewProjectTypeCompleteInventory
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033\deflangfe1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Riched20 10.0.17763}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sl240\slmult1\b\f0\fs20 Complete Inventory\b0\par \par A complete inventory project is one in which you collect data for all of the trees you are interested in. Examples of complete inventory projects may include a street tree inventory, the assessment of all or selected trees in an individual park or campus, or even an assessment of a selection of heritage or memorial trees in your town. Complete inventories can also be used to project the benefits of a planting project using the Forecast module. Complete inventory projects are most useful when detailed information is needed on each individual tree or the number of trees of interest can be assessed with a reasonable amount of effort.\par \par \b Notes:\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\sl240\slmult1\b0 Data import is only enabled for complete inventory projects and is not possible for plot-based projects.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You cannot change between Complete inventory and Plot Sample projects once you click OK so be sure to select the correct project type.\par } �

data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Reports > Benefits > Pollutant Removal by Trees > PM\sub 2.5\nosupersub\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the amount of particulate matter less than 2.5 microns (PM\sub 2.5\nosupersub ) removed by the trees in your study area estimated for each year in the future. Pollution removal value, which is an estimate of the economic value associated with the pollution removed, is also reported.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: PollutionRemovalHourlyChart
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\listtable {\list\listhybrid {\listlevel\levelnfc23\leveljc0\levelstartat1{\leveltext\'01\'B7;}{\levelnumbers;}\f2\jclisttab\tx0} {\listlevel\levelnfc23\leveljc0\levelstartat1{\leveltext\'01\'B7;}{\levelnumbers;}\f2\jclisttab\tx0}\listid1 }} {\*\listoverridetable{\listoverride\listid1\listoverridecount0\ls1}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \widctlpar\qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line Reports > Summary Charts & Tables > Ecosystem Service > Pollution Removal by Trees and Shrubs > Hourly Removal (chart)\par
\pard\widctlpar\qj\cf0\b0\par The report seen in the action panel on the right is an interactive chart that presents multiple hourly variables. The variables that you can view in this report include:\par \par
\pard {\listtext\f0\u10625?\tab}\ls1\fi-360\li1080\qj Air pollutant concentration, air quality improvement, and air pollutant flux for:\par
\pard {\listtext\f0\u10625?\tab}\ls1\ilvl1\fi-360\li1440\qj Nitrogen dioxide (NO\sub 2\nosupersub )\par {\listtext\f0 1\tab}Sulfur dioxide (SO\sub 2\nosupersub )\par {\listtext\f0 2\tab}Ozone (O\sub 3\nosupersub )\par {\listtext\f0 3\tab}Carbon monoxide (CO)\par {\listtext\f0 4\tab}Particulate matter less than 2.5 microns (PM\sub 2.5\nosupersub )\par
\pard {\listtext\f0\u10625?\tab}\ls1\fi-360\li1080\qj Photosynthetically active radiation\par {\listtext\f0 1\tab}Rain\par {\listtext\f0 2\tab}Temperature\par {\listtext\f0 3\tab}Transpiration\par
\pard\widctlpar\qj\par \b Steps:\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\qj\b0 Select the variable that you are interested in looking at by choosing it from the result view drop-down list at the top of the action panel.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}If you chose to view one of the air quality or pollution charts, then you can select the pollutant that you would like to view from the pollutant drop-down list at the top of the action panel.\par
\pard\widctlpar\li360\qj\par
\pard\widctlpar\qj\b Notes:\b0\par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\qj Particulate matter less than 10 microns (PM\sub 10\nosupersub ) is a significant air pollutant. Given that i-Tree Eco analyzes particulate matter less than 2.5 microns (PM\sub 2.5\nosupersub ) which is a subset of PM\sub 10\nosupersub , PM\sub 10\nosupersub has not been included in this analysis.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Use the tools in the Page Tools group of the ribbon above to explore this report. These tools allow you to zoom in and out, move through the pages of the report, and export or print the report seen in the action panel on the right.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to run the model again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}To change how species names and units are displayed in your reports see the View tab. You will not be required to run the model again to view the change.\par
\pard\widctlpar\li360\qj\par
\pard\widctlpar\qj For more information on the ecosystem services displayed here, please see the Glossary.\par \par
\pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\f1\fs22\lang9\par } �

data.name: WaterInterceptedTreeReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Reports > Charts > Pollution and Weather > Water Intercepted > By Trees\b0\par \pard\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the hourly water interception by trees. Water intercepted is the amount of rainfall that fell on plants and was intercepted by the plant\rquote s leaves. This water is eventually evaporated to the atmosphere. This report displays results in line chart and table formats for the user-designated weather year.\par \par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: CarbonSequestrationAreaReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Annual Carbon Sequestration of Trees > By Strata per Unit Area\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides per area (density) estimates of gross carbon sequestration of trees by strata in your study area. Per area estimates are calculated by dividing the total gross carbon sequestration in each stratum by the area of the stratum. Per area estimates are also reported for the carbon dioxide equivalent. This report displays results in bar chart and table formats.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: SendDatatoForestService
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset0 Times New Roman;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Reports > Submit Data for Processing\par \pard\b0\par After you have established your project settings in the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab and entered your field data in the \b Data\b0 tab, it is time to send your data to the server and retrieve the results for your project!\par \par When you click on the \b Submit Data for Processing\b0 button, your project settings and field data will be sent to the i-Tree server where the Eco model will be run. \par \par \b Steps:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360 In the \b Contact Information\b0 window, enter your personal information in the spaces provided.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}To confirm your email address, enter the same email address in the spaces labeled \ldblquote Email\rdblquote and \ldblquote Confirm.\rdblquote This information is critical.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Click \b OK\b0 .\par \pard\par Please be patient \endash model processing time depends on the number of projects that have been recently submitted to the server as well as the size of your project. You can click on the \b Track & Retrieve Results\b0 function to track your status in the queue.\par \par When your data have been processed, an auto-generated email notifying you that the results are ready to download will be sent to the email address that you provide in the \b Contact Information\b0 window. This email will be from info@itreetools.org; please check your spam folders if you do not receive the email. Likewise, you will be notified of processing errors that require data to be submitted again.\par \par Use the \b Track & Retrieve Results\b0\f1\fs24 \f0\fs20 function to retrieve the results for your project.\b\par \b0\par If you are unsure whether or not you have run the Eco model, you can check the \b Project Metadata\b0 report on this tab. This information is especially useful since you may find it necessary to send your data to the server more than once throughout the duration of your project (see Notes below). \par \par \b Notes:\b0 \par \pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and retrieve your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: TreeComments

data.name: AvoidedRunoffShrubReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10 \b\f0\fs20\par Reports > Charts > Pollution and Weather > Avoided Runoff > By Shrubs\b0\par \pard\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the hourly avoided runoff by shrubs. Avoided runoff is the amount of water that would become surface runoff to streams, but does not. Estimates incorporate water interception by plants, ground depression storage, infiltration on pervious ground covers, and overland flow on impervious ground covers. This report displays results in line chart and table formats for the user-designated weather year.\par \par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: HealthRptClassesForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Data > Report Classes > Crown Health\par \pard\par \b0 In the table to the right, Crown Health (either Condition or Dieback) classes that will be displayed in reports can be defined. This is limited to ten classes.\par \par \b Steps:\par \pard\fi-360\li720\b0 1.\tab When \b Editing Mode\b0 is \b On\b0 , the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par 2.\tab Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of DBH classes.\par 3.\tab The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create new classes, delete classes, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par 4.\tab In the "ID" column, enter a unique identifier for the crown health class.\par 5.\tab In the "Description" column, enter a description for the crown health class. This description will be displayed in reports that are grouped by Health Class.\par 6.\tab In the "% Dieback <=" or "% Condition >=" column, enter the upper or lower bound, respectively, that defines the range of the crown health class.\par \b\par \pard Notes:\par \pard\fi-360\li720\b0\f1\'b7\tab\f0 Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the data table here to a comma separated values (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\b\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\par } �

data.name: ForecastTotalBasalAreaReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Reports > Composition and Structure > Population Summary > Basal Area\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the total basal area of the trees in your study area estimated for each year in the future. The total basal area in Year 0 is based on the current basal area in your study area from the structural estimates provided by Eco.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: MobileRetrieveDataForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Data > Data Collection > Retrieve from Mobile\par \pard\tx720\par \pard\b0 i-Tree Eco offers multiple methods for recording the data that you collect in the field. One of these methods is to record your data using the mobile data collector. During data collection, you can access the mobile data collector from any web-enabled mobile device, such as a smartphone or tablet, and afterwards import your collected data into i-Tree Eco.\par \par The purpose of the \b Retrieve from Mobile\b0 function seen in the action panel to the right is to import the data that you collected in the field using a mobile device and the i-Tree Eco mobile data collector (see Notes below).\par \par \b Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Enter your password in the space provided and click \b Show List\b0 . Note that this password is the one you entered in the \b Submit to Mobile\b0 function when you submitted your project settings.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}To reset your password, click on the \b Reset Password\b0 button (see Notes below).\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}After you have entered your password and clicked \b Show List\b0 , a description of your data will appear.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Check the box next to the record(s) that you would like to retrieve. Each record includes a description and date to help you determine which records should be imported.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Click the \b Retrieve Data\b0 button. Your data will now be visible when you select a function from the \b Inventory Data\b0 group.\par \pard\par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 i-Tree Eco allows you to submit your project multiple times in the \b Data\b0 tab. This gives you the ability to change or tweak your project settings and then make the new version available on the mobile data collector.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}In the lower table of the action panel you can view your previously retrieved data. Please be aware that when importing data, you may want to reference this table to be sure that you retrieve the data that corresponds to the most recent mobile data collector submission.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Click on the \b Reset Password\b0 button to create a new password. A reset key will be sent to the email address provided. Enter the key and your new password in the Reset Password window that appears, and then click \b OK\b0 .\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ForecastBenefitsCarbonStorageReport

data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Reports > Benefits > Pollutant Removal by Trees > O\sub 3\nosupersub\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the amount of ozone (O\sub 3\nosupersub ) removed by the trees in your study area estimated for each year in the future. Pollution removal value, which is an estimate of the economic value associated with the pollution removed, is also reported.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ReferenceObjectsForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Data > Inventory Data > Reference Objects\par \pard\b0\par The \b Reference Objects\b0 table seen in the action panel to the right displays the reference object data for plots that you collected in the field (see Notes below). This is where you will enter your reference object data manually or edit your previously added or imported data. While working in this table, you may use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to help manually enter new data or edit data that has already been added.\par \par \pard\tx720\b Steps to Manually Add/Edit Data:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Click in the box where you would like to enter data and begin typing.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the Tab key on your keyboard or the left and right arrows to move from side to side within a record.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the up and down arrows on the keyboard to move from top to bottom between records.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}For boxes that contain drop-down lists, you can choose your data from the list or begin typing and the matching label will be automatically filled in.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}The table can be sorted by column in ascending or descending order. To sort, click on the desired column header.\par \pard\par \pard\tx720\b Steps for Using Actions Tools:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When you click on the \b Trees\b0 function, the \b Actions\b0 group will become available in the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the \b New \b0 tool to create a new record in the shrub table.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the \b Undo\b0 and \b Redo\b0 tools to correct your most recent actions (e.g., creating, editing, or deleting a record).\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Use the \b Delete\b0 tool to remove the selected record(s) from the table.\par \pard\par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you have imported your data from the mobile data collector using the \b Retrieve from Mobile \b0 function of the \b Data\b0 tab, you will see all of the imported field data for your project here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you opened a project or are working with data that was previously entered, you will see all of the field data for your project here.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Some data fields are defined on the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab. If you do not see the options you want from the drop-down list for a certain data field, you will need to go back to the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab to edit the list of options for that data field.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the shrub data here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \fi-360\li360\qj\b\par } �

Emissions are displayed for monoterpene, isoprene, and the sum of both.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: tpProjectLocation
data.value:
{tf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{ onttbl{ 0 swiss prq2 charset0 Calibri;}{ 1 swiss prq2 Calibri;}{ 2 nil charset0 Calibri;}{ 3 nil charset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;ed0\green77 lue187;ed0\green0 lue255;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard rdrb rdrs rdrw10 rsp20   0 s20\line Project Configuration > Project Definition > Location\par \pard 0\par The   Location 0 tab seen in the action panel to the right is where you identify the location of your study area and choose a local weather station.\par \par   Steps:\par \pard{\pntext 0 1.	ab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}}  i-360\li360\sa200 0 Select the location where the majority of your study area is located using the drop-down lists. Location is an important project setting because it is used to provide localized benefit estimates. That is, many of the ecosystem service analyses rely on national or finer scale location data. Identify your location as precisely as possible.\par {\pntext 0 2.	ab}Specify whether your study area is urban by checking the appropriate box. If your study area is a mix of urban and rural lands, we recommend that you answer this question based on the more dominant of the two land types. See Notes below.\par {\pntext 0 3.	ab}Enter your population values. For all locations the "Population" entered will be used in reports that include "per capita" summaries. For locations in the continental US, the "Population" entered will also be used to scale BenMAP generated health incidences and values as described in the "Pollution Removal" section of Understanding i-Tree\cf1\sub s22 1\cf0
osupersub s20 . In select locations, also enter your "Population Density" if prompted and it will be used in the regression equations described by Nowak et al.\cf1\sub 2\cf0
osupersub In some instances (e.g. a park or street tree survey) it may be appropriate to use population and/or population density values that reflect your best guess at human population receiving tree related benefits rather than the population within your project boundary.\par {\pntext 0 4.	ab}Select the weather and pollution year that you would like to use for your analysis by choosing from the drop-down list. In some cases only a weather year is available. If that choice is made, then the reports that rely on pollution data will not available.\par {\pntext 0 5.	ab}The 'Show Pollution Stations' button will display a map of pollutant data for the selected year to be used in processing. Pollutant data are pre-selected based on location and availability.\par {\pntext 0 6.	ab}If your project location is in a Tropical Region and you want to use the tropical carbon equations, check the applicable box. For additional information about this option, please see the i-Tree Eco Tropical Carbon Equations\cf1\sub 3\cf0
osupersub .\par \pard{\pntext 0 7.	ab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}}  i-360\li360 Select your weather station by clicking the   Show Map 0 button. In the window that appears, select the weather station that you would like to use in your analysis. The weather data collected at this station is used to help estimate ecosystem services, such as pollution removal. See Notes below.\par \pard\par Go through the other tabs,   Project Settings  0 and   Data Collection Options 0 , which are available in the   Project Definition 0 function. When you are satisfied with the project settings that you have entered, click   OK 0 in the top right-hand corner of the action panel.\par \par   Notes:\par \pard{\pntext 3'B7	ab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf3\pnindent0{\pntxtb'B7}} i-360\li360 0 For help classifying your study area as urban or rural, urban areas are typically defined as areas of high population density, at least 500 people per square mile (193 people per square kilometer). For additional urban land definitions, see the U.S. Census Bureau\cf1\sub 4\cf0
osupersub .\par {\pntext 3'B7	ab}Depending on data availability in the weather year you choose, certain weather stations may not be shown on the map. If there is a weather station that you know you would like to use and it does not appear on the map, you may need to change the weather year that you have selected. Otherwise, the station may not be available because it does not collect the data necessary to run the i-Tree Eco model.\par  1{\pntext 3'B7	ab}Weather data quality is categorized as either Good, Fair, or Poor based on the number of missing hourly weather data. All required weather variables, excluding precipitation, need to meet the following conditions to be classified as: Good = < 720 (8.2%) hours of missing data; Fair = <4,380 (50%) hours missing; Poor = < 8,760 (100%) hours missing. Weather stations that are completely missing data for any required variable are excluded from the weather monitor database. Missing weather data are filled in using procedures detailed  0 by Hirabayashi and Endreny\cf1\sub 5\cf0

osupersub )\par \pard\par   Steps:\par \pard{\pntext 0 1.	ab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}}  i-360\li360 0 Choose the pollutant that you would like to view by selecting it from the drop-down list at the top of the action panel.\par \pard\par   Notes:\par \pard{\pntext 1'B7	ab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb'B7}} i-360\li360 0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\par } �

The table shows the complete detailed results as well as the percent of trees affected by each sign or symptom for each stratum.\par \par \b Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 To view your results for all strata, choose the \ldblquote All Strata\rdblquote option from the drop-down list. \par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}To view your results for each of the strata individually, use the drop-down list to select the strata that you are interested in.\par \pard\par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �
