data.name: AvoidedRunoffTreeReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Reports > Charts > Pollution and Weather > Avoided Runoff > By Trees\b0\par \pard\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the hourly avoided runoff by trees. Avoided runoff is the amount of water that would become surface runoff to streams, but does not. Estimates incorporate water interception by plants, ground depression storage, infiltration on pervious ground covers, and overland flow on impervious ground covers. This report displays results in line chart and table formats for the user-designated weather year.\par \par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ForecastFunctionalAllReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Reports > Benefits > Pollutant Removal by Trees > Value for All Pollutants\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the total pollution removal value, which is an estimate of the economic value associated with pollution removed, provided by the trees in your study area estimated for each year in the future. \par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: StrataForm_full
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par \pard Project Configuration > Project & Strata Area\par \b0\par The \b Project &\b0 \b Strata Area\b0 field seen in the action panel to the right is where you can enter the area of your project or strata. This function also allows you to stratify (subdivide) your study area into smaller units, such as land use classes or counties. One reason that you might want to stratify your project is so that you can compare urban forest effects between each stratum.\par \par If you decide not to stratify your project, then you will be working with a single strata that encompasses your entire study area. Whether you choose to stratify your complete inventory or not, follow the appropriate steps below.\par \par *\b IMPORTANT\b0 *\par This function will not be available if you did not set \ldblquote Strata/Area\rdblquote during project configuration. To edit this form, go to the \b Project Definition\b0 function and check the \ldblquote Strata/Area\rdblquote box in the \b Data Collection Options\b0 tab. Then you will be able to make changes in this function. (Note: If you did not set "Strata/Area" as described, per unit area estimates will not be included in the \b Reports\b0 tab.)\par \par \b Steps for unstratified complete inventory:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When you click on the \b Project & Strata Area\b0 function, you will see a single strata listed in the table.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}If you would like to change the default strata description or abbreviation, manually edit those variables in the table (see Notes below).\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Manually enter the area of your project. This size should represent the entire sampled area of your project (see Notes below).\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}When you are satisfied with your entry, click \b OK\b0 in the top right-hand corner of the action panel. This will save the edits that you have made to the table.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Click \b Cancel\b0 if you decide to revert to all of the previous values, whether default values or those that you had previously entered manually.\par \pard\par \b Steps for stratified complete inventory:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When you click on the \b Project &\b0 \b Strata Area\b0 function, the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of strata and zones.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create or delete strata, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Manually enter strata by specifying a brief description and abbreviation in the table (see Notes below).\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Manually enter the area of each strata. This size should represent the sampled area of the strata (see Notes below).\par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}When you are satisfied with your entry, click \b OK\b0 in the top right-hand corner of the action panel. This will save the edits that you have made to the table.\par {\pntext\f0 7.\tab}Click \b Cancel\b0 if you decide to revert to all of the previous values, whether default values or those that you had previously entered manually.\par \pard\b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 The \ldblquote Description\rdblquote that you enter is used in reporting some Eco results by strata on the \b Reports\b0 tab. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}The size entered in the \ldblquote Area\rdblquote column is used to calculate the per unit area, or density, estimates that are included in some of the Eco results on the \b Reports \b0 tab. The more accurate the area entered here, the better your density estimates will be.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}The \ldblquote Tree Count\rdblquote column is automatically filled in based on the data that you enter in the \b Data\b0 tab.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the data table here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par \pard\b\par \b0 For more information on stratifying your study area, please see the \b User Manual \b0 or user guide to \b Stratifying a Complete Inventory \b0 available under \b User Guides\b0 in the \b Support\b0 tab.\par \par } �

data.name: StrataForm_plot
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Project Configuration > Project & Strata Area\par \pard\par \b0 The \b Project &\b0 \b Strata Area\b0 field seen in the action panel to the right is where you can enter the area of your project or strata. This function also allows you to stratify (subdivide) your study area into smaller units, such as land use classes or counties. One reason that you might want to stratify your project is so that you can compare urban forest effects between each stratum.\par \par If you decide not to stratify your project, then you will be working with a single strata that encompasses your entire study area. Whether you choose to stratify your plot-based sample or not, follow the appropriate steps below.\par \par \b Steps for unstratified plot-based sample:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When you click on the \b Project & Strata Area\b0 function, you will see a single strata listed in the table.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}If you would like to change the default strata description or abbreviation, manually edit those variables in the table (see Notes below).\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Manually enter the area of your project. This size should represent the entire study area of your project (see Notes below).\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}When you are satisfied with your entry, click \b OK\b0 in the top right-hand corner of the action panel. This will save the edits that you have made to the table.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Click \b Cancel\b0 if you decide to revert to all of the previous values, whether default values or those that you had previously entered manually.\par \pard\par \b Steps for stratified plot-based sample:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When you click on the \b Project &\b0 \b Strata Area\b0 function, the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of strata and zones.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create or delete strata, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Manually enter strata by specifying a brief description and abbreviation in the table (see Notes below).\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Manually enter the area of each strata. This size should represent the total area of the strata (see Notes below).\par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}When you are satisfied with your entry, click \b OK\b0 in the top right-hand corner of the action panel. This will save the edits that you have made to the table.\par {\pntext\f0 7.\tab}Click \b Cancel\b0 if you decide to revert to all of the previous values, whether default values or those that you had previously entered manually.\par \pard\b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 The \ldblquote Description,\rdblquote \ldblquote Abbreviation,\rdblquote and \ldblquote Area\rdblquote fields are informed by the \b User Defined \b0 function on this tab. If you make changes in this function or in the \b User Defined \b0 function, the changes will be reflected in both functions.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}The \ldblquote Description\rdblquote that you enter is used in reporting some Eco results by strata on the \b Reports\b0 tab. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}The size entered in the \ldblquote Area\rdblquote column is used to calculate the per unit area, or density, estimates that are included in some of the Eco results on the \b Reports \b0 tab. The more accurate the area entered here, the better your density estimates will be.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}The \ldblquote # of Plots\rdblquote column is automatically filled in based on the plots defined during plot sample creation.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the data table here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par \pard\par For more information on stratifying your study area, please see the \b User Manual \b0 or user guide to \b Pre-stratified Samples\b0 ,\b Post-stratified Samples\b0 , or \b Unstratified Samples \b0 (depending on your project goals) available under \b User Guides \b0 in the \b Support\b0 tab.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ForecastByStrataLeafBiomassAreaReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Reports > Composition and Structure > Leaf Area and Biomass > Leaf Biomass by Strata per Unit Area\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays per area (density) estimates of leaf biomass of the trees in your study area estimated for each year in the future. The leaf biomass density in Year 0 is based on the current leaf biomass in your study area from the structural estimates provided by Eco. Results are presented for each stratum in your study area.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration tab or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: InventorySummaryIndReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Individual Level Results > Composition and Structure > Of Trees\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right presents a summary of the data collected in the field as well as additional estimated tree characteristics for each of the trees sampled in your study area. This table includes Plot and Tree ID, Species Name, DBH, Height, Street Tree Status , and estimates for the following:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Canopy cover\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Tree condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Leaf area\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Leaf biomass\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Leaf area index \endash estimated by dividing leaf area by canopy cover\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Basal area\par \pard\par Tree condition categories are defined as follows according to how you choose to define crown health:\par \par \pard\li360\b Crown Health (dieback):\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Excellent = 0% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Good = 1 - 10% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Fair = 10 - 25% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Poor = 25 - 50% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Critical = 50 - 75% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Dying = 75 - 99% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Dead = 100% dieback\par \pard\li360\par \b Crown Health (condition):\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Excellent = 100% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Good = 90 - 99% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Fair = 75 - 90% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Poor = 50 - 75% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Critical = 25 - 50% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Dying = 1 - 25% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Dead = 0% condition\par \pard\par \b *IMPORTANT*\b0\par Please be aware that using custom crown health categories makes comparing results across projects more difficult and should be done with caution.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: PotentialEvapotranspirationTreeReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Reports > Charts > Pollution and Weather > Potential Evapotranspiration > By Trees\b0\par \pard\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the hourly potential evapotranspiration by trees. Potential evapotranspiration is the sum of the evaporation from the soil and the transpiration from plants that would occur if an unlimited amount of water were available. This report displays results in line chart and table formats for the user-designated weather year.\par \par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: CarbonStorageAreaReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Carbon Storage of Trees > By Strata per Unit Area\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides per area (density) estimates of carbon storage of trees by strata in your study area. data.name: WrittenReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Written Report\par \pard\b0\par The \b Written Report\b0 seen in the action panel to the right is a summary, narrative report that provides a discussion of the following results of your project:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Tree characteristics of the urban forest\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Urban forest cover and leaf area\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Ecosystem services (air pollution removal, carbon storage, etc.)\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Structural and functional values of trees\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Potential pest impacts\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}i-Tree Eco methods\par \pard\par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Some analyses included in the Written Report may not be available because of decisions not to collect certain variables in the field or data limitations in the case of international studies.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: OriginOfTreesStrataReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Species Range > Native Status by Strata\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of the percent of the trees in each stratum by native range. Possible places of origin include:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 State (for U.S. projects only)\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Africa\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Africa & Asia\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Asia\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Asia & Australia\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Asia & Australia +\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Australia\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Europe\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Europe & Africa\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Europe & Asia\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Europe & Asia +\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}North America\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}North America +\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}North & South America\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}North & South America +\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}South America\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Other\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Unknown\par \pard\par \ldblquote Unknown\rdblquote indicates that the origin of the tree species is unknown; places of origin that include two continents indicate that the tree species is native to both continents; and places of origin marked with a \ldblquote +\rdblquote indicate that the tree species is native to the place of origin listed plus another continent that is not listed. For projects in the U.S., \ldblquote State\rdblquote is an additional place of origin that is reported and refers to the state in which the study area is located.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: DBHRptClassesForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Data > Report Classes > DBH\par \pard\par \b0 In the table to the right, DBH classes that will be displayed in reports can be defined. This is limited to ten classes.\par \par \b Steps:\par \pard\fi-360\li720\b0 1.\tab When \b Editing Mode\b0 is \b On\b0 , the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par 2.\tab Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of DBH classes.\par 3.\tab The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create new classes, delete classes, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par 4.\tab Identify the lower limits of your DBH classes in the \b From\b0 column. Upper limits will automatically be provided in the \b To <=\b0 column based on the lower limit of the class that follows.\par 5.\tab To make text changes, click in the desired box on the table and you will be able to add or edit the text in that box.\par \pard\b\par Notes:\par \pard\fi-360\li720\b0\f1\'b7\tab\f0 Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the data table here to a comma separated values (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\b\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\par } �

data.name: InvCustomFieldsReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Other\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of the number of trees and percent of all trees that were designated according to a custom data field. Results are presented by the custom data field.\par \par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: SampleTreesForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue255;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20 Data > Inventory Data > Trees\par \pard\tx720\b0 February 2022\~\fs22\par \fs20\~\fs22\par \b\fs20 The Eco species list has been updated to remove synonyms and cultivars\~\b0\fs22\par \b\fs20\~\b0\fs22\par \fs20 If there are species in this project that are no longer on the Eco species list there will be exclamation symbols indicating those cells. To correct the unmatched species, click on the Check Data button at the top of the window. \~\fs22\par \fs20\~\fs22\par \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\lang9\fs20 For more information concerning this change go here: {\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "https://forums.itreetools.org/viewtopic.php?f=19&t=6486"}}{\fldrslt{\ul\cf1 https://forums.itreetools.org/viewtopic.php?f=19&t=6486}}}\lang1033\f0\fs22\par \pard\fs20 The \b Trees\b0 table seen in the action panel to the right displays the tree data that you collected in the field (see Notes below). This is where you will enter your tree data manually or edit your previously added or imported data. While working in this table, you may use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to help manually enter new data or edit data that has already been added.\par \pard\tx720\par \b Steps to Manually Add/Edit Data:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Click in the box where you would like to enter data and begin typing.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the Tab key on your keyboard or the left and right arrows to move from side to side within a record.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the up and down arrows on the keyboard to move from top to bottom between records.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}For boxes that contain drop-down lists, you can choose your data from the list or begin typing and the matching label will be automatically filled in.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}For boxes where dates are entered, a calendar pop-up will appear if you click on the calendar icon in the right-hand side of the cell. Select the date from the calendar. Click the header at the top of the pop-up to see other available months. Click the header again to see additional available years. \par \pard\li360\tx360\tx720\par \pard\tx720\b Steps for Using Actions Tools:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When you click on the \b Trees\b0 function, the \b Actions\b0 group will become available in the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the \b New \b0 tool to create a new record in the tree table.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the \b Delete\b0 tool to remove the selected record(s) from the table.\par \pard\tx720\par \pard\b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 Taxonomic classes (i.e., Magnoliopsida, Pinopsida, Ginkgoopsida, Liliopsida, Filicopsida, Cycadopsida) should be used sparingly when identifying the species of live trees. These classes can be used to represent the more generic classifications. However, species data is important to the calculation of ecosystem services \endash more specific species identification provides better model estimates.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you have imported your data from the mobile data collector using the \b Retrieve from Mobile\b0 function of the \b Data\b0 tab, you will see all of the imported field data for your project here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you opened a project or are working with data that was previously entered, you will see all of the field data for your project here.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Some data fields are defined on the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab. If you do not see the options you want from the drop-down list for a certain data field, you will need to go back to the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab to edit the list of options for that data field.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the tree data here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you recorded the GPS coordinates (latitude and longitude) of each tree during field data collection, you will be able to make use of Eco's \b KML\b0 function. Use the \b KML\b0 function in the ribbon to export the tree data here to a "keyhole markup language" (kml) file. Data exported as a kml file are compatible with software programs that include Google Earth and ArcGIS and allow you to view tree locations spatially.\par \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\par Use this workbook, {\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "https://www.itreetools.org/documents/736/Synonym_Lookup_Form.xlsx"}}{\fldrslt{\ul\cf1 https://www.itreetools.org/documents/736/Synonym_Lookup_Form.xlsx}}}\f0\fs20 , to lookup the scientific and common names i-Tree recognizes.\lang9\par \i For more information: \i0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "https://www.itreetools.org/support/resources-overview/i-tree-manuals-workbooks"}}{\fldrslt{\ul\cf1 https://www.itreetools.org/support/resources-overview/i-tree-manuals-workbooks}}}\lang1033\b\f0\fs20\par } �

data.name: PlotsForm
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Riched20 10.0.17763}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par
\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Data > Inventory Data > Plots\par
\pard\tx720\par Note: Editing is left to right, one row at a time.\par \par \b0 The \b Plots\b0 function seen in the action panel to the right is where you can enter or edit the plot data that you collected in the field (see Notes below). The upper table displays your plot data. While working in this table, you may use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to help manually enter new data or edit data that has already been added.\par \par \b Steps to Viewing Plot Data:\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When you click on a record in the plot table, additional plot data will be displayed in the table below it.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the tabs located at the bottom of the action panel to view different plot data in the lower table.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Hide the lower table by clicking on the pin button in the upper right-hand corner of the table.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Unhide the lower table by clicking on one of the tabs at the bottom of the action panel and clicking on the pin button again.\par
\pard\tx720\par \b Steps to Manually Add/Edit Data:\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Click in the box where you would like to enter data and begin typing.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the Tab key on your keyboard or the left and right arrows to move from side to side within a record.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the up and down arrows on the keyboard to move from top to bottom between records.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}For boxes that contain drop-down lists, you can choose your data from the list or begin typing and the matching label will be automatically filled in.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}The table can be sorted by column in ascending or descending order. To sort, click on the desired column header.\par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}For boxes where dates are entered, a calendar pop-up will appear if you click on the calendar icon in the right-hand side of the cell. Select the date from the calendar. Click the header at the top of the pop-up to see other available months. Click the header again to see additional available years.\par
\pard\tx720\par \b Steps for Using Actions Tools:\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When you click on the \b Plots\b0 function, the \b Actions\b0 group will become available in the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the \b New \b0 tool to create a new record in the plot table.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the \b Undo \b0 and \b Redo \b0 tools to correct your most recent actions (e.g., creating, editing, or deleting a record).\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Use the \b Delete\b0 tool to remove the selected record(s) from the table.\par
\pard\tx720\par \b Notes:\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you have imported your data from the mobile data collector using the \b Retrieve from Mobile\b0 function of the \b Data\b0 tab, you will see all of the imported field data for your project here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you opened a project or are working with data that was previously entered, you will see all of the field data for your project here.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Some data fields are defined on the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab. If you do not see the options you want from the drop-down list for a certain data field, you will need to go back to the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab to edit the list of options for that data field.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the plot data here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you recorded the GPS coordinates (latitude and longitude) of plot center during field data collection, you will be able to make use of Eco's \b KML\b0 function. Use the \b KML\b0 function in the ribbon to export the plot data here to a "keyhole markup language" (kml) file. Data exported as a kml file are compatible with software programs that include Google Earth and ArcGIS and allow you to view plot locations spatially.\par
\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: TemperatureKelvinReport

This report displays results in line chart and table formats for the user-designated weather year.\par \par \b Notes:\par \b0\f1\'b7 \f0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to run the model again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par \f1\'b7 \f0 Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ManagementCostsExpenditureReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Management Costs > By Expenditure \par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right displays the user-defined expenditures for managing the trees in your study area. From the total costs reported, the cost per tree and cost per capita are also estimated and presented in this table.\par \par Management costs are defined by the user in the \b Annual Costs\b0 function of the \b Data \b0 tab. To edit your annual costs, open that function and follow the steps outlined in the \b Help\b0 panel. Annual costs can be edited at any time and you will not be required to submit your project again. Results on the \b Reports\b0 tab will reflect the change in annual costs immediately.\par \par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: forumButton
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue255;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Support > User Forum\par \pard\par \b0 The webpage seen in the action panel to the right provides an access point where you can participate in a moderated discussion forum to solicit advice, get technical questions answered, communicate experiences, and view frequently asked questions (FAQs).\par \par \pard\sl276\slmult1 Also available at:\par {\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "https://forums.itreetools.org/"}}{\fldrslt{\ul\cf1 https://forums.itreetools.org/}}}\b\f0\fs20\par \par } �

data.name: NumberOfTreesStrataAreaReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Population Summary > By Strata per Unit Area\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides per area (density) estimates of the number of trees found in each stratum in your study area. Per area estimates are calculated by dividing the total number of trees in each stratum by the area of the stratum. This report displays results in bar chart and table formats.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ForecastParameterSummaryReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Configuration Summary\par \pard\b0\tab\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays all of the parameters that you defined for the active configuration. This includes parameters defined under the \b Basic Options\b0 function, such as number of years to forecast, frost-free days, and base annual mortality rates, as well as any additional mortality rates or tree planting and extreme event scenarios that you defined. If you have chosen to run Forecast using the defaults provided, you will see those values here as well.\par \par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: EnableEditing_ProjectConfig
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Riched20 10.0.10586}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\line Project Configuration > Editing Mode \par
\pard\par \b0 The settings that you choose in the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab provide an important base for your i-Tree Eco project. The \b Editing Mode\b0 function helps to prevent unintentional changes to your project configuration.\par
\pard\tx720\par
\pard After you send data and retrieve results on the \b Reports\b0 tab, the \b Editing Mode \b0 function will become available on the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab (i.e., it will no longer be greyed out and the function will read \ldblquote Editing Mode: Off\rdblquote ). This indicates that the tab is in View-only mode so each function may be viewed, but not edited.\par \par However, the project settings that you enter in this tab may be edited with caution. In order to do this, you will need to switch to Editing mode by clicking on the \b Editing Mode \b0 function once it has become available. After clicking on it, the function will be greyed out and read \ldblquote Editing Mode: On.\rdblquote Edits may be made at that time.\fs22 \fs20 Please note that if you edit your project configuration, the results in the \b Reports\b0 tab may not reflect the changes that you made. To ensure that they do, send your data to the server and load your results again.\par \par } �

data.name: StructuralValueDBHSpeciesReport
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Riched20 10.0.19041}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Replacement Value > By DBH Class and Species \par
\pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides total estimates of the replacement value of trees in your study area by species and DBH size class. Results also include total replacement value for each species with estimated standard error as well as the percent contribution of each species to the total replacement value of your urban forest.\par \par \b Notes:\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par
\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: UserActions
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \widctlpar\qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par Data > Data Edit Tools\par
\pard\widctlpar\qj\tx720\cf0\par \b0 The data editing tools include: New, Copy, Undo, and Delete. These tools can be used when manually entering field data or editing data that has already been added. Please note that the tools will be greyed out and unavailable when you are not working directly with your data.\par \par \b Steps:\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\qj\tx720\b0 While working in the Plots, Trees, or Shrubs function of the Data ribbon, select a record or multiple records from the table in the action panel to the right.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the New data editing tool to create a new record in the table.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the Copy tool to duplicate the selected record(s) in the table.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Use the Undo tool to undo the last typing or editing (e.g., creating, duplicating, or deleting a record) that was done in the table.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Use the Delete tool to remove the selected record(s) from the table.\par
\pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\f1\fs22\lang9\par } �

data.name: PlantingSitesForm
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \widctlpar\qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line Data > Add or Edit Data > Planting Sites\par
\pard\widctlpar\qj\cf0\par
\pard\widctlpar\qj\tx720\b0 The Planting Sites table seen in the action panel on the right displays your planting site data that you collected in the field (see Notes below). This is where you will enter your planting site data manually or edit your previously added or imported data. While working in this table, you may use the data editing tools to help manually enter field data or edit data that has already been added.\par \par \b Steps to Manually Add/Edit Data:\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\qj\tx720\b0 Click in the box where you would like to enter data and begin typing.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the Tab key or left and right arrows on the keyboard to move from side to side within a record.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the up and down arrows on the keyboard to move from top to bottom between records.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}For boxes that contain drop-down lists, you can choose your data from the list or begin typing\'85\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}The table can be sorted by column in ascending or descending order. To sort, click on the column header that you would like to sort your data by.\par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}To filter data, click on the column header that you would like to filter by.\par
\pard\widctlpar\qj\tx720\par \b Steps for Using Data Edit Tools:\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\qj\tx720\b0 While working in the Planting Sites function of the Data ribbon, select a record or multiple records from the table in the action panel to the right.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the New data editing tool to create a new record in the table.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the Copy tool to duplicate the selected record(s) in the table.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Use the Undo tool to undo the last typing or editing (e.g., creating, duplicating, or deleting a record) that was done in the table.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Use the Delete tool to remove the selected record(s) from the table.\par
\pard\widctlpar\qj\tx720\par \b Notes:\par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\qj\tx720\b0 Collecting planting site data is optional!\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}If you have imported your data from the mobile webform using the Retrieve Data function of the Data tab, you will see all of the imported field data for your project here. \par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}If you opened a project or are working with data that was previously entered, you will see all of the field data for your project here.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Some data fields are defined on the Project Configuration tab. If you do not see the options you want from the drop-down list for a certain data field, you will need to go back to the Project Configuration tab to edit the list of classes for that data field.\par
\pard\widctlpar\qj\tx720\par
\pard\widctlpar\qj For more information on the data collection variables, go to:\par
\pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\f1\fs22\lang9\par } �

data.name: AQImpTreeReport
data.value:
{tf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{ onttbl{ 0 swiss prq2 charset0 Calibri;}{ 1 nil charset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard rdrb rdrs rdrw10 rsp20 \qj  0 s20\par \pard rdrb rdrs rdrw10 rsp20 Reports > Charts > Pollution and Weather > Air Quality Improvement > By Trees 0\par \pard\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the hourly air quality improvement provided by the tree cover in your study area. This report displays results in line chart and table formats for the user-designated pollution year. Estimates are reported for the following pollutants:\par \par \pard{\pntext 1'B7	ab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb'B7}} i-360\li720 Nitrogen dioxide (NO\sub 2
osupersub )\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Sulfur dioxide (SO\sub 2
osupersub )\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Ozone (O\sub 3
osupersub )\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Carbon monoxide (CO)\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Particulate matter less than 2.5 microns (PM\sub 2.5
osupersub )\par \pard\par   Steps:\par \pard{\pntext 0 1.	ab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}}  i-360\li360 0 Choose the pollutant that you would like to view by selecting it from the drop-down list at the top of the action panel.\par \pard\par   Notes:\par \pard{\pntext 1'B7	ab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb'B7}} i-360\li360 0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\par } �

MaintRecTotalsLookupReport
