Results are presented by recommeded maintenance type and species.\par \pard\par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\lang9\f1\fs22\par } �

data.name: FoodscapeBenefitsOfTreesBySpecies
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green102\blue255;\red0\green0\blue255;\red5\green99\blue193;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\sa160\sl252\slmult1\b\f0\fs20 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Foodscape Benefits of Trees > By Species\par \b0 The report seen in the action panel to the right provides information about the characteristics, productivity and services provided by edible/useful species of trees. It is intended to communicate the value of this subset of trees in order to guide users in the planning, management and selection of the appropriate species.\par Only those species for which data has been gathered are included in the report. Additionally, if an entry in the report is blank, no data is currently available for that attribute. In the future, more species will be added. These data were gathered by the \cf1\ul{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "http://inhabit.earth/community-food-forestry" }}{\fldrslt{\cf3 Community Food Forestry Initiative}}}\cf1\ulnone\f0\fs20 \cf0 (CFFI).\par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par \pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\sa160\sl252\slmult1\b\fs22 \b0\fs20 You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\b\fs22\par \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\lang9\b0\f1\par }

data.name: WireConflictTotalsLookupReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Maintenance > Utility Conflicts by Species\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of the number of trees, percent of species, and percent of all trees that were designated as posing a utility conflict. Results are presented by type of utility conflict and species.\par \par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: WildLifeSuitabilityByPlots
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Avian Habitat Suitability > By Plot\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of avian habitat suitability for each plot in your study area. The suitability index reported here is a unitless value meant to capture the ability of an area to sustain a population based on the habitat features that relate to and influence the patterns of abundance of each species. Two suitability index values are given for each plot. One value is based on the trees that were sampled on the plot and the other value assumes an absence of trees on the plot.\par \par The index change due to trees is estimated as the following:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 A relative change calculated as the absolute change (see below) divided by the suitability index with trees.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}An absolute change calculated as the suitability index with trees minus the suitability index without trees.\par \pard\par The avian species reported here are based on their ranges so only those species present in the study area will be included in the report. Data is available for up to nine bird species, including American robin, Baltimore oriole, black-capped chickadee, Carolina chickadee, European starling, northern cardinal, red-bellied woodpecker, scarlet tanager, and wood thrush.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: CustomFieldsForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Project Configuration > Define Data Fields > Custom Fields\par \pard\par \b0 The \b Custom Fields\b0 option allows you to define up to three additional variables to collect during tree assessment. For example, if you\rquote re interested in invasive species, you can classify each tree assessed as invasive or not (y/n). Custom data fields cannot be open-ended, but must be divisible into specific categories.\par \b\par \b0 The list displayed here shows the custom field entries to choose from in a mobile data collector, as well as in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon. Your final custom list should encompass all of the possibilities for that type of data relevant to your study area.\par \b\par Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When you click on the \b Custom\b0 \b Fields\b0 function, the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of possible data entries.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create or delete data categories, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}In the \ldblquote Description\rdblquote column of the table, manually enter the data categories for that custom field.\par \pard\b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 Your custom fields must first be defined in the \b Data Collection Options \b0 tab of the \b Project Definition \b0 function. To add, edit, or delete the custom fields that appear in the ribbon above, go back to the \b Data Collection Options \b0 tab.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the data table here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: SpeciesCompositionDBHStrataReport_hor
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Species Distribution > By DBH Class and Strata (horizontal table)\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of the proportion of trees of each species by strata found in each diameter at breast height (DBH) size class. Results are displayed for the percent of the tree species population by DBH class and include estimates of standard error. If all DBH classes cannot fit across the top of the table, the horizontal display breaks results into several tables so you can scroll to the right through all DBH classes.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: tpProjectInfo
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Project Configuration > Project Definition > Project Settings\par \pard\b0\par The \b Project Settings\b0 tab seen in the action panel to the right is where you identify many of your most important project settings.\par \par \b Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\sa200\b0 Enter a name for your project in the box provided. Your project name gives your i-Tree Eco project a unique identity. This is also the name that will be used when referring to your study area in your model results (available on the \b Reports\b0 tab of the ribbon).\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Enter a series name for your project in the box provided. Again, your series name helps to give your project a unique identity. It can be used to identify the exact nature of the project \endash for example, \ldblquote ParkTrees\rdblquote or \ldblquote City\rdblquote \endash to distinguish it from other Eco projects done at the same time in the same place, if necessary. This series name can be used in the future to reference the data for this project.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Enter a series year in the box provided. It is recommended that you enter the year of your data collection for this variable.\par \pard{\pntext\f0 4.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360 The inventory type does not need to be defined. This information is automatically filled in based on the project type that you defined when you started a new project.\par \pard\par Go through the other tabs, \b Location \b0 and \b Data Collection Options\b0 , which are available in the \b Project Definition\b0 function. When you are satisfied with the project settings that you have entered, click \b OK\b0 in the top right-hand corner of the action panel.\par \par } �

data.name: InventorySummarySpeciesReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Individual Level Results > Composition and Structure > Of Trees By Species\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right presents a summary of the data collected in the field as well as additional estimated tree characteristics for each of the trees sampled in your study area. This table includes estimates for the following characteristics:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Tree count\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Canopy cover\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Leaf area\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Leaf biomass\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Basal area\par \pard\par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ForecastPercentTreeCoverReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Reports > Composition and Structure > Population Summary > Percent Tree Cover\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the percent tree cover in your study area estimated for each year in the future. The percent tree cover in Year 0 is based on the current tree cover in your study area from the structural estimates provided by Eco.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: TreeConditionSpeciesReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Condition > By Species\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of the percent of each tree species found in each condition class. The following condition classes are included in the table:\par \par \pard\li360\b Report Categories (dieback):\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Excellent = 0% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Good = 1 - 10% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Fair = 10 - 25% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Poor = 25 - 50% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Critical = 50 - 75% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Dying = 75 - 99% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Dead = 100% dieback\par \pard\li360\par \b Report Categories (condition):\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Excellent = 100% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Good = 90 - 99% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Fair = 75 - 90% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Poor = 50 - 75% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Critical = 25 - 50% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Dying = 1 - 25% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Dead = 0% condition\par \pard\par \b *IMPORTANT*\b0\par Please be aware that using custom crown health categories makes comparing results across projects more difficult and should be done with caution.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par } �

data.name: LandUsesDataForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Data > Inventory Data > Land Uses\par \pard\b0\par The \b Land Uses\b0 table seen in the action panel to the right displays the land use data for plots that you collected in the field (see Notes below). This is where you will enter your land use data manually or edit your previously added or imported data. While working in this table, you may use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to help manually enter new data or edit data that has already been added.\par \par \pard\tx720\b Steps to Manually Add/Edit Data:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Click in the box where you would like to enter data and begin typing.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the Tab key on your keyboard or the left and right arrows to move from side to side within a record.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the up and down arrows on the keyboard to move from top to bottom between records.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}For boxes that contain drop-down lists, you can choose your data from the list or begin typing and the matching label will be automatically filled in.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}The table can be sorted by column in ascending or descending order. To sort, click on the desired column header.\par \pard\par \pard\tx720\b Steps for Using Actions Tools:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When you click on the \b Trees\b0 function, the \b Actions\b0 group will become available in the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the \b New \b0 tool to create a new record in the shrub table.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the \b Undo\b0 and \b Redo\b0 tools to correct your most recent actions (e.g., creating, editing, or deleting a record).\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Use the \b Delete\b0 tool to remove the selected record(s) from the table.\par \pard\par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you have imported your data from the mobile data collector using the \b Retrieve from Mobile \b0 function of the \b Data\b0 tab, you will see all of the imported field data for your project here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you opened a project or are working with data that was previously entered, you will see all of the field data for your project here.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Some data fields are defined on the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab. If you do not see the options you want from the drop-down list for a certain data field, you will need to go back to the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab to edit the list of options for that data field.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the shrub data here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \fi-360\li360\qj\b\par } �

data.name: EnableEditing_Forecast
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Editing Mode\par \pard\par \b0 After you run Forecast, the \b Editing Mode \b0 function will become available on the ribbon (i.e., it will no longer be greyed out and the function will read \ldblquote Editing Mode: Off\rdblquote ). This indicates that the \b Forecast\b0 tab is in View-only mode so each function may be viewed, but not edited. Your reports can still be viewed, saved, and printed. \par \par However, if you decide that you would like to make changes to your active configuration, you will need to switch to Editing mode by clicking on the \b Editing Mode \b0 function once it has become available. After clicking on it, the function will be greyed out and read \ldblquote Editing Mode: On.\rdblquote Please note that this will clear all of the reports on the \b Forecast\b0 tab that are associated with this configuration and you will be required to \b Run Forecast \b0 to view those reports again.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: NewProjectTypePlotSample
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033\deflangfe1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Riched20 10.0.17763}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sl240\slmult1\b\f0\fs20 Plot Sample\b0\par \par A plot-based sample project is one in which you must measure a set of randomly generated plots throughout your study area. You must collect data for all of the trees in your plots. This type of project is most applicable to the analysis of a broad, diverse landscape, such as a city or large university campus where it is impractical to measure all trees. Plot sample type projects do include calculations of sampling error which results when only a subset of the population of interest is being measured.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\sl240\slmult1 Data import is only enabled for complete inventory projects and is not possible for plot-based projects.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You cannot change between Complete inventory and Plot Sample projects once you click OK so be sure to select the correct project type.\par } �

data.name: ForecastFunctionalSO2Report
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Reports > Benefits > Pollutant Removal by Trees > SO\sub 2\nosupersub \par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the amount of sulfur dioxide (SO\sub 2\nosupersub ) removed by the trees in your study area estimated for each year in the future. Pollution removal value, which is an estimate of the economic value associated with the pollution removed, is also reported.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: RelativePerformanceIndexSpeciesReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Relative Performance Index > By Species\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of relative performance index (RPI) by tree species. RPI compares the overall condition of each species to all the others. Values that are higher than 1 indicate that a species has a proportionately better condition rating.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: PlantingSiteTypesForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\line Project Configuration > Define Data Fields > Planting Site Type\par \pard\qj\par \b0 The planting site type field seen in the action panel on the right is a category that identifies the kind of planting site (e.g., planting strip, cutout) of each tree sampled in your study area. During data collection, you can record the planting site type of each tree that you collect data for. Determining the site type is useful for comparisons with tree conflicts and maintenance recommendations and tasks for understanding problem planting sites for specific species. \par \par The list displayed here is used for the planting site type options to choose from in the webform if you collect your field data using a mobile device, as well as in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon. The final list of site types should include all of the classes that exist in your study area (see Notes below). i-Tree Eco includes 7 default planting site types to choose from (see Descriptions below), but you may add or edit site types to customize your project.\par \par \b Steps:\par \b0 1. When you click on the \b Planting Site Type\b0 function, the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par 2. Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of planting site types.\par 3. The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create new classes, delete classes, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par 4. Manually enter or edit planting site types by entering a brief description in the description column of the table.\par 5. Enter the size associate with each planting site type in the size column.\par \b\par Descriptions:\par \b0\f1\'b7 \f0 Front yard \endash self-explanatory.\par \par \f1\'b7 \f0 Planting strip \endash the narrow strip of grass or planted area that separates a roadway curb or road shoulder from a right-of way line (such as a sidewalk).\par \par \f1\'b7 \f0 Cutout \endash unpaved space within a paved area such as a sidewalk that is designated for planting; also referred to as a treepit or tree well.\par \par \f1\'b7 \f0 Median \endash reserved strip within a roadway that separates lanes of traffic that are moving in opposite directions.\par \par \f1\'b7 \f0 Other maintained locations \endash sites that are regularly impacted by mowing, weeding, herbicide applications, etc. (e.g., commercial properties, parks).\par \par \f1\'b7 \f0 Other unmaintained locations \endash sites that are not regularly impacted by mowing, weeding, herbicide applications, etc.\par \par \f1\'b7 \f0 Backyard \endash self-explanatory.\par \par \b Notes:\par \b0\f1\'b7 \tab\f0 The planting site types that are displayed here will be available in the webform if you collect your field data using a mobile device, as well as in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon. If you are unsure what site types you will see in the field, we recommend that you keep all of the defaults so they will all be available to choose from.\b\par \b0\f1\'b7 \f0 Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the data table here to a comma separated values (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par \par } �

data.name: LeafAreaBiomassTreesDBHStrataReport_hor
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Leaf Area and Biomass > Of Trees by DBH Class and Species (horizontal display)\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of leaf area and leaf biomass for each tree species. Results are displayed by diameter at breast height (DBH) size class and include estimates of standard error. If all DBH classes cannot fit across the top of the table, the horizontal display breaks results into several tables so you can scroll to the right through all DBH classes.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: PrintPaperForms
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \widctlpar\qj\b\f0\fs20\line Project Configuration > Paper Forms > Print \par
\pard\widctlpar\qj\par \b0 i-Tree Eco offers multiple methods for recording the data that you collect in the field. One of these methods is to record your data on paper forms. When you select the Print function, you can print the paper forms.\par \par \b Steps:\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\qj\b0 Select the printer that you would like to use.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Click Print.\par
\pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\f1\fs22\lang9\par } �

data.name: BenefitPricesForm
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \nowidctlpar\b\f0\fs20\par Data > Inventory Value > Benefit Prices\par
\pard\nowidctlpar\ri-1170\par
\pard\nowidctlpar\b0 i-Tree Eco calculates the monetary value associated with the ecosystem services (e.g., carbon storage) provided by the trees, shrubs and grasses in your study area.\par \par The \b Benefit\b0 \b Prices\b0 function seen in the action panel to the right provides advanced users with the opportunity to adjust the default benefit prices that are used by the model. Please use this function with caution!\par \par Already submitted your project to the Eco server and retrieved your results? No problem \endash this form can be edited at any time and you will not be required to submit your project again. Results on the \b Reports\b0 tab will reflect the change in valuation immediately.\par \par To define your benefit prices, do one of the following for each benefit price:\par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\nowidctlpar\fi-360\li360 Click on the \b Default\b0 button to use the defaults available with this version of Eco;\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Leave the space blank to use the most current default values; or\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Manually enter the benefit prices that you would like the model to use by overwriting the default values or previously entered values in the boxes.\par
\pard\nowidctlpar\par \b Steps:\b0\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \nowidctlpar\fi-360\li360 The measurement units shown in the space provided match the units specified in the \b Data Collection Options \b0 tab of the \b Project Definition \b0 function.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Define each benefit price using one of the methods above.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}When you are satisfied with the benefit prices you have set, click \b OK\b0 in the top right-hand corner of the action panel. This will save the edits that you have made to the prices.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Click \b Cancel\b0 if you decide to revert to all of the previous values, whether default values or those that you had previously entered manually. \par
\pard\nowidctlpar\b\par *IMPORTANT*\par \b0 For international users doing a project outside of the U.S., please enter a currency exchange rate in the space provided or click on the \b Get today\rquote s rate \b0 button for current exchange rates. The current exchange rates are provided courtesy of openexchangerates.org. For benefit prices, we encourage you to provide your own valuation data. If you do not have local data, make use of Eco\rquote s default benefit prices as described in Step 2. These defaults are U.S. prices that are converted to your local currency using the exchange rate provided. For users doing a project in Australia, Canada, or the UK, default prices are specific to each country.\b\par \par Notes:\par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 The reports for grasses will be available only when the location is in 48 US continental states and ground cover information is collected.\par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\nowidctlpar\fi-360\li360 Next to each of the benefit prices, the units (e.g., $/kWh) are listed in parentheses. When manually entering benefit prices, take note of these units and be sure that the benefit prices you define match the units listed.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}If you are working with the latest version of the Eco application, then the defaults available will also be the most current default values.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}To view the benefit prices used in your results, look at the \b Project Metadata \b0 report on the \b Reports\b0 tab or look in the footnotes of your benefit reports.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the benefit prices here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par
\pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\f1\fs22\lang9\par } �

data.name: PopSumStreetTreesStrataReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Population Summary > Street Trees by Strata\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of the number of trees and percent of trees that were designated as street trees or non-street trees. Street tree and non-street tree results are summarized in separate tables by strata.\par \par The tables display the following information:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b Number of Trees\b0 \endash number of trees in stratum that were classified as street trees or non-street trees.\par \pard\fi-360\li720\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b % of Strata Trees \b0\endash percent of trees in stratum that were classified as street trees or non-street trees. For example, in the \ldblquote Summary of Street Trees\rdblquote table, 100% would indicate that all trees located in that stratum were classified as street trees.\par \pard\fi-360\li720\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b % of Street Trees\b0 \endash percent of all trees classified as street trees that were located in each stratum. For example, 50% would indicate that half of all street trees were located in that stratum. \par \pard\fi-360\li720\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b % of Non-Street Trees\b0 \endash percent of all trees classified as non-street trees that were located in each stratum. For example, 25% would indicate that one quarter of all non-street trees were located in that stratum. \par \pard\fi-360\li720\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b % of All Trees\b0 \endash percent of the total number of trees that were classified as street trees or non-street trees and located in each stratum. For example, in the \ldblquote Summary of Street Trees\rdblquote table, 0% would indicate that none of the total number of trees were classified as street trees \i and\i0 located in that stratum.\par \pard\fi-360\li720\par \pard\b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: ForecastLeafAreaIndexReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Reports > Composition and Structure > Leaf Area and Biomass > Leaf Area Index\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the leaf area index of the trees in your study area estimated for each year in the future. Leaf area index is the total one-sided leaf surface area per unit of ground surface area. It is estimated by dividing the leaf area by the ground area. The leaf area index in Year 0 is based on the current leaf area index in your study area from the structural estimates provided by Eco.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: SpeciesCompositionDBHStrataReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Resource Structural Analysis > Species Composition > By DBH Class and Strata\par \pard\qj\b0\par The table seen in the action panel on the right provides estimates how many of each tree species by strata is found in each diameter at breast height (DBH) class. Results are displayed for the percent of the tree species population by DBH class and the standard error.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \f1\'b7 \f0 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par \f1\'b7 \f0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to run the model again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par \f1\'b7 \f0 Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par \f1\'b7 \f0 You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\par } �

data.name: MaintenanceForm
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \widctlpar\qj\b\f0\fs20\line Project Configuration > Define Data Fields > Maintenance\par
\pard\widctlpar\qj\par \b0 For plot-based sample: OPTIONAL\par For complete inventory: OPTIONAL\par \par The list displayed here is used for the maintenance options to choose from in the webform if you collect your field data using a mobile device, as well as in the Data tab of the ribbon. The final list of maintenance options should include all of the classes that exist in your study area (see Notes below). i-Tree Eco includes 6 default recommended maintenance types to choose from, but you may add up to 4 additional maintenance types to customize your project. i-Tree Eco includes 7 default priority task types to choose from, but you may add up to 3 additional mainetance types to customize your project.\par \par The maintenance field seen in the action panel on the right includes two categories: recommended maintenance (e.g., routine maintenance for small tree, immediate maintenance for large tree) and priority task (e.g., clean crown, treat pests). During data collection, you would record the recommended maintenance and priority task of each tree that you collect data for. Determining the maintenance needs of the trees will help with prioritizing, planning and budgeting for future tree care activities. \par \par \b Steps:\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\qj\b0 Manually enter maintenance types (up to 4 for recommended maintenance and up to 3 for priority tasks) by entering a brief description in the description column of the appropriate table.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}To select one of the maintenance types, check the box at the beginning of the record (note: you may select more than one record at a time).\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the records toolbar available above the top right corner of the table to copy or delete selected records.\par
\pard\widctlpar\qj\par \b Notes:\par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\qj\b0 The maintenance types that are displayed here will be available in the webform if you collect your field data using a mobile device, as well as in the Data tab of the ribbon. If you are unsure what maintenance types you will see in the field, we recommend that you keep all of the defaults so they will all be available to choose from.\f1\fs22\lang9\par } �

data.name: UVIndexReductionTreeShadeReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue255;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Report > Charts > Pollution and Weather > UV Index Reduction by Trees > Effects in Tree Shade\par \pard\par \b0 The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the daily reduction in UV index by trees in your study area. Ultraviolet (UV) radiation is emitted by the sun and while beneficial to humans in small doses, can have negative health effects when people are overexposed. The UV index scale was developed by the World Health Organization to more easily communicate daily levels of UV radiation and alert people to when protection from overexposure is needed most. UV index values are estimated from UV radiation and adjusted based on local elevation and cloud cover. Tree canopies help to reduce the amount of UV radiation that reaches the ground thus providing people with additional protection from the sun\rquote s harmful rays. \par \par Effects in tree shade are changes in UV for a person who is always shaded by tree canopy. For example, someone who is sitting under a tree. Reduction in UV Index in tree shade is calculated as unshaded UV index minus shaded UV index. This report displays results in line chart and table formats. UV data is from the same year as the user-designated weather and pollution year. It is presented as a daily reduction at solar noon when the sun is highest in the sky.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 For more information on the UV index scale, visit {\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "http://www.who.int/uv/intersunprogramme/activities/uv_index/en/"}}{\fldrslt{\ul\cf1 http://www.who.int/uv/intersunprogramme/activities/uv_index/en/}}}\f0\fs20\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Support > User Guides\par \pard\b0\par The \b User Guides\b0 seen in the action panel to the right provide topic-specific information to help users work through specific tasks for their project. The tree cover area in Year 0 is based on the current tree cover in your study area from the structural estimates provided by Eco.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: SpeciesCodesForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par View > Species > Species Codes\par \pard\par \b0 Tree species can be identified in i-Tree Eco by their unique species code (e.g., ACRU), scientific name (e.g., Acer rubrum), or common name (e.g., Red Maple). The \b Species Codes\b0 lookup tool seen in the action panel to the right identifies the species code, scientific name, and common name associated with a tree species when you supply one of the three. For example, if you know that the common name of one of your tree species is Red Maple, then supplying that name in the lookup tool will provide you with the corresponding species code and scientific name.\par \par \b Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Use one of the drop-down lists to select a species code, scientific name, or common name.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}The lookup tool will provide the corresponding information for that tree species in the other two boxes.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\par } �

data.name: RunModels
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Run Models\par \pard\b0\par After you have established your project settings in the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab and entered your field data in the \b Data\b0 tab, it is time to run the i-Tree Eco model and get the results for your project!\par \par After you click on the \b Run Models\b0 button, the i-Tree Eco model will begin running. Please be patient \endash a progress bar will appear and indicate when the run has completed. You will see that many of the reporting options listed in the ribbon bar are greyed out and unavailable until after the model has been run.\par \par If you are unsure whether or not you have run the Eco model, you can check the \b Project Metadata\b0 report of this tab. The \b Project Metadata\b0 report will inform you whether or not the model has been run and the timestamp for the most recent run. This information is especially useful since you may find it necessary to run the i-Tree Eco model more than once throughout the duration of your project (see Notes below). \par \par \b Notes:\b0 \par \pard\fi-360\li360\f1\'b7\tab\f0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to run the model again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ExportPlotsToFileDialog
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \widctlpar\qj\b\f0\fs20\par Project Configuration > Define Plots > Export Plot Data\par
\pard\widctlpar\qj\par \b0 i-Tree Eco allows you to export the plot information in two different formats (i.e., csv or kml). Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad. Plot data exported as a kml file are compatible with software programs that include Google Earth and ArcGIS.\par \b\par Steps:\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\qj\b0 Click on the button to export your plot data as either a csv or kml file.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Navigate to the folder where you would like to save your file.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Click OK.\par
\pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\f1\fs22\lang9\par } �

data.name: SpeciesCompositionDBHReport_hor
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Species Distribution > By DBH Class (horizontal table)\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of the proportion of trees of each species found in each diameter at breast height (DBH) size class. Results are displayed for the percent of the tree species population by DBH class and include estimates of standard error. If all DBH classes cannot fit across the top of the table, the horizontal display breaks the results into several tables so you can scroll to the right through all DBH classes.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: CarbonStorageSpeciesReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Carbon Storage of Trees > By Species\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides total estimates and percent contribution of carbon storage of trees by species in your study area. Results are also reported in carbon dioxide equivalent by multiplying carbon storage by the ratio of their atomic weights (44/12). This report displays results in table format.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: EnableConfig
rtSupport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs20\par To get started, go to the \b File\b0 menu and select one of the following options:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b New Project\b0 \endash to create a new Eco project.\par \b{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Open Project \b0\endash to open an existing Eco project.\par \b{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Open Example Project \b0\endash to open and explore an example project provided by Eco. \par \pard\par Choose from the available tabs at the top of the ribbon bar to access the different phases of an Eco project. Within each tab, you can click on one of the functions or buttons in the ribbon above. The feature that you choose will become available in the action panel to the right.\par \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\lang9\f1\fs22\par } �

data.name: TreeCharacteristicsReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset2 Symbol;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Individual Tree Details > Tree Characteristics\par \pard\qj\b0\par The table seen in the action panel on the right presents a summary of the data collected in the field and additional estimated tree characteristics for each of the trees sampled in your study area. This table includes estimates for the following characteristics:\par \par \pard\fi-360\li720\qj\f1\'b7\tab\f0 Species name\par \f1\'b7\tab\f0 DBH\par \f1\'b7\tab\f0 Height\par \f1\'b7\tab\f0 Ground area\par \f1\'b7\tab\f0 Tree condition\par \f1\'b7\tab\f0 Leaf area\par \f1\'b7\tab\f0 Leaf biomass\par \f1\'b7\tab\f0 Leaf area index\par \f1\'b7\tab\f0 Carbon storage\par \f1\'b7\tab\f0 Gross carbon sequestration\par \f1\'b7\tab\f0 Compensatory value\par \f1\'b7\tab\f0 Street tree\par \f1\'b7\tab\f0 Native to state\par \pard\qj\par \b Notes:\b0\par \f1\'b7 \f0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to run the model again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par \f1\'b7 \f0 Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par \f1\'b7 \f0 You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\lang9\f2\fs22\par } �

This report displays results in pie chart and table formats.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: SpeciesListForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par View > Species > Species List\par \pard\par \b0 Tree species can be identified in i-Tree Eco by their unique species code (e.g., ACRU), scientific name (e.g., Acer rubrum), or common name (e.g., Red Maple). The \b Species List\b0 table seen in the action panel to the right identifies the species code, scientific name, and common name of all of the tree species that are available in Eco. This list can be exported to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file for use outside of Eco. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par \par \b Steps to Export List:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Click on the \b CSV\b0 function.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Navigate to the folder where you would like to save your file.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Enter a file name.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Click \b Save\b0 .\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\par } �

data.name: ForecastFunctionalNO2Report
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Reports > Benefits > Pollutant Removal by Trees > NO\sub 2\nosupersub\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the amount of nitrogen dioxide (NO\sub 2\nosupersub ) removed by the trees in your study area estimated for each year in the future. Pollution removal value, which is an estimate of the economic value associated with the pollution removed, is also reported.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ModelNotesReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Reports > Model Notes\b0\par \pard\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides more information about the data processing that occurs within the Eco model. For example, notes here may indicate that energy data collected for a specific tree was invalid and therefore the estimated energy effects do not include that specific tree. Use the key below the processing notes to decipher any errors that occurred and determine how to resolve them.\par \par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\qj You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\par } �

data.name: ImportDataForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Data > Data Collection > Import\par \pard\tx720\par \pard\b0 Do you have an existing inventory? The \b Import\b0 function in the \b Data Collection \b0 group allows you to import your existing tree inventory data. This tool is only available for complete inventory projects and is generally greyed out in the ribbon until you click on the \b Trees \b0 function.\par \par \b Steps to Import Inventory:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\ri20\sl276\slmult1 In the \b Data Import Wizard\b0 , click \b Browse\b0 .\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Navigate to the file containing your inventory data. \par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Select the file and click \b Open\b0 .\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Confirm that the data that appears in the table is correct and click \b Next\b0 .\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Match your existing data fields to Eco\rquote s data fields.\par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}Select an inventory column from the table. The column header will appear in the \ldblquote Your Source Column\rdblquote space towards the bottom of the window.\par {\pntext\f0 7.\tab}Choose the \ldblquote Eco Field\rdblquote from the drop-down list that defines the type of data in your selected column.\par {\pntext\f0 8.\tab}Check the box indicating whether or not you will need to map your field values to the Eco field values. (Note: You will be prompted to complete the value mapping later. See steps 12 through 16.)\par {\pntext\f0 9.\tab}CONDITIONALLY REQUIRED: As previously described, Eco data variables can often be displayed in several ways. For example, species data can be entered as common name, scientific name, or species code. For data variables where this applies, a \ldblquote Field Type\rdblquote drop-down list will appear below \ldblquote Eco Field.\rdblquote Select the field type that matches your existing data.\par {\pntext\f0 10.\tab}Repeat steps 6 through 9 until each variable that you would like imported has been matched to the appropriate Eco field.\par {\pntext\f0 11.\tab}Click \b Next\b0 .\par {\pntext\f0 12.\tab}CONDITIONALLY REQUIRED: For data variables that you indicated the need to map field values (step 8), match your field values to Eco\rquote s.\par {\pntext\f0 13.\tab}In the upper table, select a row.\par {\pntext\f0 14.\tab}In the lower table, choose the \ldblquote Eco Value\rdblquote from the drop-down list that matches \ldblquote Your Value.\rdblquote \par {\pntext\f0 15.\tab}Move through the lower table until all of your values have been matched to an Eco value.\par {\pntext\f0 16.\tab}Repeat steps 12 through 15 until all necessary data variables have been mapped.\par {\pntext\f0 17.\tab}Click \b Next\b0 .\par {\pntext\f0 18.\tab}Review the results of your processed data at the top of the \b Data Import Wizard\b0 . This information will tell you how many records from your inventory data will be imported.\par {\pntext\f0 19.\tab}When you are satisfied with the data that will be imported, click \b Finish\b0 . (Note: Use the \b Back\b0 button to return to previous steps to make adjustments.) \par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Leaf Area and Biomass > Of Trees by DBH Class and Species (vertical display)\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of leaf area and leaf biomass for each tree species. data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Benefits Summary > By Species\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides a summary of Eco\rquote s benefit estimates, including number of trees, carbon storage and sequestration, avoided runoff, pollution removal, and structural value, for each species in your study area.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ShrubsForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Data > Inventory Data > Shrubs\par \pard\b0\par The \b Shrubs\b0 table seen in the action panel to the right displays the shrub data that you collected in the field (see Notes below). This is where you will enter your shrub data manually or edit your previously added or imported data. While working in this table, you may use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to help manually enter new data or edit data that has already been added.\par \par \pard\tx720\b Steps to Manually Add/Edit Data:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Click in the box where you would like to enter data and begin typing.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the Tab key on your keyboard or the left and right arrows to move from side to side within a record.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the up and down arrows on the keyboard to move from top to bottom between records.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}For boxes that contain drop-down lists, you can choose your data from the list or begin typing and the matching label will be automatically filled in.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}The table can be sorted by column in ascending or descending order. To sort, click on the desired column header.\par \pard\par \pard\tx720\b Steps for Using Actions Tools:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When you click on the \b Trees\b0 function, the \b Actions\b0 group will become available in the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the \b New \b0 tool to create a new record in the shrub table.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the \b Undo\b0 and \b Redo\b0 tools to correct your most recent actions (e.g., creating, editing, or deleting a record).\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Use the \b Delete\b0 tool to remove the selected record(s) from the table.\par \pard\par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you have imported your data from the mobile data collector using the \b Retrieve from Mobile \b0 function of the \b Data\b0 tab, you will see all of the imported field data for your project here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you opened a project or are working with data that was previously entered, you will see all of the field data for your project here.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Some data fields are defined on the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab. If you do not see the options you want from the drop-down list for a certain data field, you will need to go back to the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab to edit the list of options for that data field.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the shrub data here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \fi-360\li360\qj\b\par } �

This report displays charts and tables for the following pollutants:\par \par \pard{\pntext 1'B7	ab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb'B7}} i-360\li720 Nitrogen dioxide (NO\sub 2
osupersub )\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Sulfur dioxide (SO\sub 2
osupersub )\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Ozone (O\sub 3
osupersub )\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Carbon monoxide (CO)\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Particulate matter less than 2.5 microns (PM\sub 2.5
osupersub )\par \pard\par Several of the charts and tables in this report present pollution removal and the associated value for all of the pollutants studied. The remaining charts show pollution removal and value for the pollutants individually.\par \par   Notes:\par \pard{\pntext 1'B7	ab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb'B7}} i-360\li360 0 While particulate matter smaller than 10 microns (PM\sub 10
osupersub ) is a significant air pollutant, it is not included in this analysis because i-Tree Eco analyzes particulate matter less than 2.5 microns (PM\sub 2.5
osupersub ), which is a subset of PM\sub 10
osupersub . PM\sub 2.5
osupersub is generally more relevant in discussions concerning air pollution effects on human health.\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard rdrb rdrs rdrw10 rsp20 \qj \par } �
