data.name: ForecastMortalityForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Forecast > Custom Options > Annual Mortality Rates\par \pard\b0\par The \b Annual Mortality Rates\b0 function seen in the action panel to the right can be used to customize your Forecast results at a more advanced level. \par \par Please note that making changes here is \ul optional\ulnone . If you would like to use the i-Tree Eco defaults, do not make changes in this action panel. If you have already supplied all of the mortality information that you would like to use in the \b Basic Options\b0 function, then do not make further changes in this action panel (see Notes below).\par \par If you decide you would like to pursue the advanced mortality options, you must define all of the following variables:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\sa200\b Mortality type \b0\endash i-Tree Eco base mortality rates are based on the following classes: healthy trees with 0-49% dieback, sick trees with 50-74% dieback, and dying trees with 75-99% dieback. This variable allows you to define mortality rates for a specific class such as a genus of tree, condition of tree, or specific stratum of the study area.\par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Annual mortality rate (%) \b0\endash i-Tree Eco default base mortality rates are 3.0% for trees with 0-49% dieback, 13.08% for sick trees with 50-74% dieback, and 50% for dying trees with 75-99% dieback. The rate that you provide indicates the percent of trees that will die each year in the class chosen for mortality type. For example, you can choose to model a scenario where all trees identified in the genus Acer have a mortality rate of 1%. In this case, projections for all other trees would use the default base mortality rates or base mortality rates defined by you in the \b Basic Options\b0 function.\par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Percent of Starting Population? \b0\endash i-Tree Eco default assumption is that mortality is calculated on an annual basis. Alternatively, you may choose to calculate mortality based on the starting population. Use these examples to help you decide:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li1080\sa200\b Annual basis \b0\endash Let\rquote s say that from our i-Tree Eco results we have 100 healthy trees. If we apply the default 3.0% mortality rate for healthy trees, 3 of those 100 healthy trees will die in the first year. In the second year, the tree mortality would be 3.0% of the remaining 97 healthy trees, which is another 2.91 trees. In the third year, the tree mortality would be 3.0% of 94.09 trees, or 2.8227 trees, and so on.\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li1080\b Percent of starting population \b0\endash Let\rquote s say that from our i-Tree Eco results we have a starting population of 100 healthy trees. If we apply the default 3.0% mortality rate for healthy trees, then 3 of those trees will die each year. One scenario where this option would be most useful is if you are planning tree removal at a constant rate. For example, emerald ash borer is a pest that can have a devastating impact on ash tree populations. As part of your study area\rquote s management plan, you may choose to remove a certain number of ash trees each year. \par \pard\par \b Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Choose your mortality type from the drop-down list. After you select your mortality type, a second drop-down list to the right will be populated with additional options.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}From that second drop-down list, choose the class that you will be defining your mortality rate for. For example, if you choose genus as your mortality type, then you can choose a genus class (e.g., Acer) from the second drop-down list.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Define the annual mortality rate for the mortality type and class specified by either typing the rate directly in the box provided or using the up and down arrows on your keyboard to increase or decrease the number.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Specify if you would like to calculate tree mortality as a percent of the starting population (see examples above) by checking the box next to the label \b Percent of Starting Population\b0 .\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}To delete the advanced mortality options that you defined, click on the \b Clear \b0 button.\par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}Once you have defined a mortality type and class and mortality rate that you are satisfied with, click the \b Add\b0 button.\par {\pntext\f0 7.\tab}Your advanced mortality options will appear in the table at the bottom of the action panel.\par {\pntext\f0 8.\tab}You may choose to include multiple advanced mortality options.\par {\pntext\f0 9.\tab}Use the toolbar located above the upper left-hand corner of the table to undo, redo, or delete advanced mortality options in the table.\par \pard\b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 The Forecast component of i-Tree Eco estimates the future structure and function of your urban forest by incorporating anticipated growth and mortality rates. This provides you with an estimate of what your urban forest will look like in the future. You can even include future tree planting scenarios or possible adverse events, such as a storm or pest infestation, to predict their impact on your urban forest.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}When defining mortality rates by genus, common name is listed in the drop-down list with scientific name in parentheses.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: MonoterpeneByTrees
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Charts > Pollution and Weather > Monoterpene > By Trees\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right displays hourly estimates of the monoterpene emmissions of all trees in your study area. This report displayes results in line chart and table formats for the project's weather year.\line\par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par } �

data.name: Print
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \widctlpar\qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line Data > Print\par
\pard\widctlpar\qj\tx720\cf0\par \b0 i-Tree Eco offers a print function so you can print a copy of the field data record that you have selected. Please note that this tool will be greyed out and unavailable when you are not working directly with your data.\par \par \b Steps:\b0\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\qj\tx720 While working in the Plots, Trees, or Shrubs function of the Data ribbon, select a record or multiple records from the table in the action panel to the right.\b\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\qj\b0 Select the printer that you would like to use.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Click Print.\par
\pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\f1\fs22\lang9\par } �

data.name: MaintenanceTaskForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Project Configuration > Define Data Fields > Maintenance > Maintenance Task\par \pard\par \b0 The \b Maintenance Task\b0 field seen in the action panel to the right identifies a variety of typical maintenance tasks. During data collection, you can record the maintenance task for each tree assessed. Determining the maintenance needs of the trees will help with prioritizing, planning, and budgeting for future tree care activities. There are seven default maintenance tasks (e.g., crown clearing), but we strongly encourage users to define maintenance tasks that are relevant to their project goals.\par \b\par \b0 The list displayed here is used for the maintenance task options to choose from in a mobile data collector, as well as in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon. Your final list of task options should include all of the maintenance tasks that are relevant to your study area. \par \b\par Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When \b Editing Mode \b0 is \b On\b0 , the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of maintenance tasks.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create or delete maintenance tasks, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}In the \ldblquote Description\rdblquote column of the table, manually enter or edit maintenance tasks.\par \pard\b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 Use the \b CSV \b0 function in the ribbon to export the data table here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: DefinePlotsViaGoogleMapsForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Project Configuration > Define Plots > via Google Maps\par \pard\par \b0 If you are conducting a plot-based sample, you need to define the plots where you will be collecting your data. The \b via\b0 \b Google\b0 \b Maps\b0 function seen in the action panel to the right is one of the methods for defining your plots. This option allows you to create a sample of plots using Google Maps directly in i-Tree Eco.\par \par The random plot generator tool requires you to define the boundary of your study area by providing a GIS shapefile or drawing the boundary yourself. Your sample of plots is then created by randomly distributing plot points throughout your study area. Because these plots are randomly placed, they may fall on rooftops, in water bodies, and in other areas that may seem undesirable. This is the nature of random sampling. However, we recommend that you generate a few extra plots in case some are inaccessible.\par \par There are three different options for generating your plots through Google Maps (see Descriptions below).\par \par \b Steps for Option 1 \endash Simple Random (shapefile boundary):\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Have an ESRI ArcGIS shapefile of the boundary of your project area ready. You must have the shp, dbf, and shx files associated with this boundary and the shapefile must be in geographic projection (latitude/longitude).\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Select \b Simple random (shapefile boundary)\b0 next to \b Options\b0 .\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Click on the \b Browse\b0 buttons next to each of the shapefile boxes in turn.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}For each shapefile box, navigate to the GIS shapefile that you have ready and click \b Open\b0 . (Note: The shapefiles that you enter must be in shp, dbf, and shx formats.) Be sure to select the appropriate format for each entry.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Click on the \b Proceed to random plot generation\b0 button.\par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}Click \b OK\b0 to proceed.\par {\pntext\f0 7.\tab}Indicate how large your sample plots should be by either leaving \ldblquote 0.1 Acres is the standard plot size\rdblquote selected or entering a custom plot size or radius in the box provided.\par {\pntext\f0 8.\tab}Indicate how many sample plots you would like by entering the number of plots or percent of the project area that you would like to sample in the boxes provided. (Note: The project area based on your study area boundary is shown below the Google Map display.)\par {\pntext\f0 9.\tab}Click on the \b Generate random sample plots\b0 button.\par {\pntext\f0 10.\tab}Click \b OK\b0 .\par \pard\b\par Steps for Option 2 \endash Simple Random (user drawn boundary):\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Select \b Simple random (user drawn boundary)\b0 next to \b Options\b0 .\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Click on the \b Proceed to random plot generation\b0 button.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Enter the approximate location of your study area in the space provided and click \b Go\b0 . The map in the Google Map display should zoom to that location.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Use the navigation and zoom tools on the right-hand side of the map display to adjust the view of your study area.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Use the \b Map\b0 and \b Satellite\b0 buttons at the top of the map display to toggle those displays on and off.\par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}To draw your boundary, click on the \b Draw a polygon\b0 tool located above the upper left-hand corner of the map display. While this tool is active, click on the map to start drawing your boundary. Click at each spot where you would like to add a point to your boundary. Double-click to finish the drawing.\par {\pntext\f0 7.\tab}To delete a boundary that you have drawn, first click on the polygon to select it and then right-click on the polygon. Click on the \b X\b0 button that appears.\par {\pntext\f0 8.\tab}When you have a boundary that you are satisfied with, click on the \b Done and Continue\b0 button.\par {\pntext\f0 9.\tab}Indicate how large your sample plots should be by either leaving \ldblquote 0.1 Acres is the standard plot size\rdblquote selected or entering a custom plot size or radius in the box provided.\par {\pntext\f0 10.\tab}Indicate how many sample plots you would like by entering the number of plots or percent of the project area that you would like to sample in the boxes provided. (Note: The project area based on your study area boundary is shown below the Google Map display.)\par {\pntext\f0 11.\tab}Click on the \b Generate random sample plots \b0 button.\par {\pntext\f0 12.\tab}Click \b OK\b0 .\par \pard\b\par Steps for Option 3 \endash Stratified Random (shapefile boundary):\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Have an ESRI ArcGIS shapefile of the boundary of your project area ready. This boundary must be divided into the polygons that represent your strata. You will be asked to select one column in your shapefile\rquote s data table to stratify by. Each stratum can be composed of multiple disjoint polygons. You must have the shp, dbf, and shx files associated with this boundary and the shapefile must be in geographic projection (latitude/longitude).\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Select \b Stratified random (shapefile boundary) \b0 next to \b Options\b0 .\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Click on the \b Browse\b0 buttons next to each of the shapefile boxes in turn.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}For each shapefile box, navigate to the GIS shapefile that you have ready and click \b Open\b0 . (Note: The shapefiles that you enter must be in shp, dbf, and shx formats.) Be sure to select the appropriate format for each entry.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Click on the \b Proceed to random plot generation\b0 button.\par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}Click \b OK\b0 to proceed.\par {\pntext\f0 7.\tab}Choose a field from the drop-down menu that will be used for stratification.\par {\pntext\f0 8.\tab}Click \b Continue\b0 .\par {\pntext\f0 9.\tab}Indicate how large your sample plots should be by either leaving \ldblquote 0.1 Acres is the standard plot size\rdblquote selected or entering a custom plot size or radius in the box provided.\par {\pntext\f0 10.\tab}Indicate how many sample plots you would like to have in each stratum by entering the number of plots or percent of the project area that you would like to sample in the boxes provided. (Note: The project area based on your study area boundary is shown below the Google Map display.)\par {\pntext\f0 11.\tab}Click on the \b Generate random sample plots \b0 button.\par {\pntext\f0 12.\tab}Click \b OK\b0 .\par \pard\b\par Descriptions:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Simple Random (shapefile boundary) \b0\endash Use this option if you already have a GIS shapefile boundary defined for your area of interest. All of your plots will be randomly distributed within that boundary. Simple random sampling will generate plot locations as random sets of latitude and longitude coordinates within your boundary. This is the most basic type of sampling and is appropriate for most projects where you would like summaries for your entire area of interest.\par \pard\fi-360\li360\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b Simple Random (user drawn boundary) \b0\endash Use this option if you do not have a GIS shapefile defining the boundary of your area of interest. You will draw your boundary using Google Maps. All of your plots will be randomly distributed within that boundary. Simple random sampling will generate plot locations as random sets of latitude and longitude coordinates within your boundary. This is the most basic type of sampling and is appropriate for most projects where you would like summaries for your entire area of interest.\par \pard\fi-360\li360\b\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Stratified Random (shapefile boundary) \b0\endash Use this option if you already have a GIS shapefile with strata boundaries defined for your area of interest and you want to select how many plots to distribute randomly within each stratum. Your shapefile must have a field in the attribute table indicating the categories you want to stratify by. Stratified random sampling is a more advanced type of sampling than simple random sampling. It allows you to define naturally occurring categories or strata within your area of interest. Strata can be based on any categories you choose. Common examples include land use categories, ownership categories, or neighborhoods. The advantages of stratified random sampling are that you can summarize results by your categories and concentrate sampling in the strata you are most interested in. You can also increase the precision of your population estimates (i.e., decrease standard error) by defining strata so that you would expect plots within a stratum to be relatively similar while you would expect plots from different strata to be relatively dissimilar.\par \pard\li360\b\par \pard\b0 For more information on stratifying your study area, please see the \b User Manual\b0 or user guide to \b Pre-stratified Samples\b0 ,\b Post-stratified Samples\b0 , or \b Unstratified Samples \b0 (depending on your project goals) available under \b User Guides \b0 in the \b Support\b0 tab.\par \par } �

data.name: LockConfiguration
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\line Project Configuration > Enable Editing\par \pard\qj\par \b0 The settings that you choose in the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab provide an important base for your i-Tree Eco project. The \b Enable Editing\b0 function helps to prevent unintentional changes to your project configuration.\par \par After you run the Eco model in the \b Reports\b0 tab, the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab will be locked so it cannot be edited unintentionally.\par \par The project settings that you enter in the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab may be edited with caution. In order to do this, you will need to switch to editing mode by clicking on \b Enable Editing\b0 function when you access the tab. However, please note that you will need to run the model again if you make any changes to your project configuration.\par \par } �

data.name: StructureSummaryStrataSpeciesReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Structure Summary > By Strata and Species\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides a summary of Eco\rquote s structural estimates, including number of trees, leaf area, leaf biomass, tree biomass, and average condition, for the tree species in each stratum in your study area.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: NetCarbonSequestrationSpeciesReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Annual Net Carbon Sequestration of Trees > By Species\b0\par \pard\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides total estimates of net carbon sequestration of trees by species in your study area. Net sequestration is a measure of the carbon sequestered by trees calculated as the gross carbon sequestered minus the carbon emissions due to decomposition after tree death. Results are also reported in carbon dioxide equivalent by multiplying carbon sequestration by the ratio of their atomic weights (44/12). This report displays results in table format.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

Results are presented by type of sidewalk conflict, species, and DBH size classes.\par \par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

CheckData
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue255;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20 Data > Inventory Data > Check Data\par \pard\tx720\b0 February 2022\par \par \b The Eco species list has been updated to remove synonyms and cultivars\par \par \b0 If there are species in this project that are no longer on the Eco species list there will be exclamation symbols indicating those cells. To correct the unmatched species, click on the Check Data button at the top of the window. \par \par \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\lang9 For more information concerning this change go here: {\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "https://forums.itreetools.org/viewtopic.php?f=19&t=6486"}}{\fldrslt{\ul\cf1 https://forums.itreetools.org/viewtopic.php?f=19&t=6486}}}\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \i i-Tree Manuals, Guides & Workbooks: \i0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "https://www.itreetools.org/support/resources-overview/i-tree-manuals-workbooks"}}{\fldrslt{\ul\cf1 https://www.itreetools.org/support/resources-overview/i-tree-manuals-workbooks}}}\lang1033\b\f0\fs20\par } �

data.name: MobileSubmitInventoryForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Data > Data Collection > Submit to Mobile\par \pard\par \b0 i-Tree Eco offers multiple methods for recording the data that you collect in the field. One of these methods is to record your data using the mobile data collector. You can access the mobile data collector from any web-enabled mobile device, such as a smartphone or tablet, and import your collected data into i-Tree Eco from the web (also available on \b Data\b0 tab of ribbon). The Eco mobile device functionality is not an app that you have to download from a store; it is a web-based inventory data collection form. \par \par The purpose of the \b Submit to Mobile\b0 function seen in the action panel to the right is to send your project configuration to the server where you will be able to access it using a mobile device and the i-Tree Eco mobile data collector (see Notes below).\par \par \b *IMPORTANT*\par \b0 Before you can start working with the mobile data collector on your mobile device, you must submit your project configuration here (see Notes below). \i If you do not submit your project configuration, you will not be able to access the mobile data collector from your mobile device.\i0\par \par \b Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Enter and confirm your email address in the space provided on the right-hand side of the action panel.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Enter and confirm your password in the space provided on the right-hand side of the action panel.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Select all of the records that you want submitted to the mobile data collector.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Click \b Submit Project\b0 .\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Check the email account that you provided for instructions on accessing the i-Tree Eco mobile data collector for your project.\par \pard\li360\par \pard\b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 i-Tree Eco allows you to submit your project multiple times. This gives you the ability to change or tweak your project settings and then make the new version available on the mobile data collector.\par \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\lang9\f1\fs22\par } �

data.name: SidewalkConflictForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Project Configuration > Define Data Fields > Maintenance > Sidewalk Conflict\par \pard\par \b0 The \b Sidewalk Conflict\b0 field seen in the action panel to the right identifies the extent of damage to sidewalks from nearby trees. During data collection, you can record any sidewalk conflicts for each tree assessed. Determining the maintenance needs of the trees will help with prioritizing, planning, and budgeting for future tree care activities. There are three default measurements of sidewalk heaving (e.g., > 1\'bd inches), but we strongly encourage users to define sidewalk conflicts in a way that is relevant to their project goals.\par \b\par \b0 The list displayed here is used for the sidewalk conflict options to choose from in a mobile data collector, as well as in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon. Your final list of sidewalk conflict options should include all of the types that are relevant to your study area.\par \b\par Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When \b Editing Mode\b0 is \b On\b0 , the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of sidewalk conflict types.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create or delete sidewalk conflict types, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}In the \ldblquote Description\rdblquote column of the table, manually enter or edit sidewalk conflicts.\par \pard\li360\tx360\b\par \pard Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the data table here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: ForecastByStrataLeafAreaIndexReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Forecast > Reports > Composition and Structure > Leaf Area and Biomass > Leaf Area Index by Strata\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the leaf area index of the trees in your study area estimated for each year in the future. Leaf area index is the total one-sided leaf surface area per unit of ground surface area. It is estimated by dividing the leaf area by the ground area. The leaf area index in Year 0 is based on the current leaf area index in your study area from the structural estimates provided by Eco. Results are presented for each stratum in your study area.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: rtReports
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs20\par To get started, go to the \b File\b0 menu and select one of the following options:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b New Project\b0 \endash to create a new Eco project.\par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Open Project \b0\endash to open an existing Eco project.\par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Open Example Project \b0\endash to open and explore an example project provided by Eco. \par \pard\par Choose from the available tabs at the top of the ribbon bar to access the different phases of an Eco project. Within each tab, you can click on one of the functions or buttons in the ribbon above. The feature that you choose will become available in the action panel to the right.\par \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\par } �

data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Charts > Pollution and Weather > Isoprene > By Trees\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right displays hourly estimates of the isoprene emmissions of all trees in your study area. This report displayes results in line chart and table formats for the project's weather year.\line\par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par } �

data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Support > License Agreement\par \pard\b0\par The \b License Agreement \b0 option provides you with the i-Tree Eco End User\rquote s License Agreement that you agree to when you download the i-Tree software and run an Eco project.\par \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\par } �

data.name: LeafAreaStrataAreaTreesChart
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Leaf Area > By Strata per Unit Area\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides per area (density) estimates of the leaf area found in each stratum in your study area. Per area estimates are calculated by dividing the total leaf area in each stratum by the area of the stratum. This report displays results in bar chart and table formats.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: StreetsForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Project Configuration > Define Data Fields > Street Names\par \pard\par \b0 The street name field seen in the action panel on the right is a category that can be used to help describe the location of the trees sampled in your study area. During data collection, you can record the street name of each tree that you collect data for. Although these street names will not be reported, they can be helpful when looking through your records in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon especially if your project is focused on the street trees of a study area.\par \par The list that you create here is used for the street name options to choose from in the mobile data collector if you collect your field data using a mobile device, as well as in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon. The final list of street names should include all of the streets that exist in your study area (see Notes below).\par \b\par Steps:\par \pard\fi-360\li720\b0 1.\tab When you click on the \b Street Names\b0 function, the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par 2.\tab Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of street names.\par 3.\tab The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create new classes, delete classes, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par 4.\tab Manually enter the street names that you will encounter in the field, by entering the names in the \b Name\b0 column of the table.\b\par \pard\par Notes:\par \pard\fi-360\li360\b0\f1\'b7\tab\f0 The street names that are displayed here will be available in the mobile data collector if you collect your field data using a mobile device, as well as in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon.\b\par \b0\f1\'b7\tab\f0 Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the data table here to a comma separated values (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\b\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\par } �

data.name: SpeciesCompositionDBHReport

This table includes estimates for the following energy effects:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Effect on building energy use (i.e., increases or decreases in the number of MBTUs and KWHs used for heating or cooling residential buildings in study area)\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Value of effects (i.e., values associated with the changes in building energy use)\par \pard\par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Trees for which no building information was collected are excluded from this report.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Negative values in the table indicate an \ul increase\ulnone in building energy use or values due to the tree sampled. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: NetCarbonSequestrationStrataReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Annual Net Carbon Sequestration of Trees > By Strata\b0\par \pard\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides total estimates of net carbon sequestration of trees by strata in your study area. Net sequestration is a measure of the carbon sequestered by trees calculated as the gross carbon sequestered minus the carbon emissions due to decomposition after tree death. Results are also reported in carbon dioxide equivalent by multiplying carbon sequestration by the ratio of their atomic weights (44/12). This report displays results in bar chart and table formats.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: UVIndexReductionOverallReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue255;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Report > Charts > Pollution and Weather > UV Index Reduction by Trees > Effects Overall\par \pard\par \b0 The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the daily reduction in UV index by trees in your study area. Ultraviolet (UV) radiation is emitted by the sun and while beneficial to humans in small doses, can have negative health effects when people are overexposed. The UV index scale was developed by the World Health Organization to more easily communicate daily levels of UV radiation and alert people to when protection from overexposure is needed most. UV index values are estimated from UV radiation and adjusted based on local elevation and cloud cover. Tree canopies help to reduce the amount of UV radiation that reaches the ground thus providing people with additional protection from the sun\rquote s harmful rays. \par \par Overall effects are changes in UV for a person who is in both areas that are shaded by tree canopy and areas that are not. For example, someone who is walking down a street may find themselves under tree canopy at some times and exposed to full UV radiation at others. Reduction in UV Index overall is calculated as unshaded UV index minus overall UV index. This report displays results in line chart and table formats. UV data is from the same year as the user-designated weather and pollution year. It is presented as a daily reduction at solar noon when the sun is highest in the sky.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 For more information on the UV index scale, visit {\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "http://www.who.int/uv/intersunprogramme/activities/uv_index/en/"}}{\fldrslt{\ul\cf1 http://www.who.int/uv/intersunprogramme/activities/uv_index/en/}}}\f0\fs20\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\lang9\f1\fs22\par } �

data.name: rtForecast
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs20\par To get started, go to the \b File\b0 menu and select one of the following options:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b New Project\b0 \endash to create a new Eco project.\par \b{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Open Project \b0\endash to open an existing Eco project.\par \b{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Open Example Project \b0\endash to open and explore an example project provided by Eco. \par \pard\par Choose from the available tabs at the top of the ribbon bar to access the different phases of an Eco project. Within each tab, you can click on one of the functions or buttons in the ribbon above. The feature that you choose will become available in the action panel to the right.\par \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\lang9\f1\fs22\par } �

data.name: NewProjectTypeReinventory
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033\deflangfe1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sl240\slmult1\b\f0\fs20 Re-inventory\b0\par \par A re-inventory project is one in which you plan to remeasure trees that you previously collected data for. For example, you may have collected data for all of the trees within a park in 2004. In 2014, you decided that you would like to go back to the same park and collect data for the trees again. One of the reasons why you might want to complete a re-inventory project would be to analyze how the urban forest in your study area is changing over time.\par \par If you are planning to do a re-inventory project, be sure that it is selected in the drop-down list above, and then click \b OK\b0 .\par \par If you are not sure that this project type is the right choice for you, select one of the other project types from the drop-down list to see a description of the other options.\fs22\lang9\par } �

data.name: LeafNutrientsBySpeciesReport
NetCarbonSequestrationAreaReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Annual Net Carbon Sequestration of Trees > By Strata per Unit Area\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides per area (density) estimates of net carbon sequestration of trees by strata in your study area. Net sequestration is a measure of the carbon sequestered by trees calculated as the gross carbon sequestered minus the carbon emissions due to decomposition after tree death. Per area estimates are calculated by dividing the total net carbon sequestration in each stratum by the area of the stratum. Per area estimates are also reported for the carbon dioxide equivalent. This report displays results in bar chart and table formats.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: NetAnnualBenefitsReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Net Annual Benefits > Net Annual Benefits for All Trees \par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right displays the economic value of the environmental benefits provided by all of the trees in your study area. The user-defined management costs are reported so that net benefits and benefit-cost ratio can be estimated for your study area. From the total benefits and costs reported, per tree and per capita estimates are also presented in this table.\par \par Management costs are defined by the user in the \b Annual Costs\b0 function of the \b Data \b0 tab. To edit your annual costs, open that function and follow the steps outlined in the \b Help\b0 panel. Annual costs can be edited at any time and you will not be required to submit your project again. Results on the \b Reports\b0 tab will reflect the change in annual costs immediately.\par \par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

\pard\ri-1170\par
\pard The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the hourly air quality improvement provided by the grass/herbaceous cover in your study area. This report displays results in line chart and table formats for the user-designated pollution year. Estimates are reported for the following pollutants:\par \par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Nitrogen dioxide (NO\sub 2\nosupersub )\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Sulfur dioxide (SO\sub 2\nosupersub )\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Ozone (O\sub 3\nosupersub )\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Carbon monoxide (CO)\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Particulate matter less than 2.5 microns (PM\sub 2.5\nosupersub )\par
\pard\par \b Steps:\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Choose the pollutant that you would like to view by selecting it from the drop-down list at the top of the action panel.\par
\pard\par \b Notes:\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 These reports are shown only when the location is in 48 US continental states and ground cover information is collected.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par

\pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\par } �

data.name: TreeConditionStrataReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Condition > By Strata and Species\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of the percent of each tree species by strata found in each condition class. The following condition classes are included in the table:\par \par \pard\li360\b Report Categories (dieback):\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Excellent = 0% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Good = 1 - 10% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Fair = 10 - 25% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Poor = 25 - 50% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Critical = 50 - 75% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Dying = 75 - 99% dieback\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Dead = 100% dieback\par \pard\li360\par \b Report Categories (condition):\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Excellent = 100% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Good = 90 - 99% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Fair = 75 - 90% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Poor = 50 - 75% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Critical = 25 - 50% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Dying = 1 - 25% condition\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Dead = 0% condition\par \pard\par \b *IMPORTANT*\b0\par Please be aware that using custom crown health categories makes comparing results across projects more difficult and should be done with caution.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: SpeciesCompositionDBHReport_vert
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Species Distribution > By DBH Class (vertical table)\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of the proportion of trees of each species found in each diameter at breast height (DBH) size class. Results are displayed for the percent of the tree species population by DBH class and include estimates of standard error. If all DBH classes cannot fit across the top of the table, the vertical display breaks the results into several tables so you can scroll down through all species in your study area before reaching the remaining DBH classes.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ForecastTotalLeafBiomassAreaReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Reports > Composition and Structure > Leaf Area and Biomass > Leaf Biomass per Unit Area\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays per area (density) estimates of leaf biomass of the trees in your study area estimated for each year in the future. The leaf biomass density in Year 0 is based on the current leaf biomass in your study area from the structural estimates provided by Eco.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration tab or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: SiteTypesForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\line Project Configuration > Define Data Fields > Planting Site Type\par \pard\qj\par \b0 The planting site type field seen in the action panel on the right is a category that identifies the kind of planting site (e.g., planting strip, cutout) of each tree sampled in your study area. During data collection, you can record the planting site type of each tree that you collect data for. Determining the site type is useful for comparisons with tree conflicts and maintenance recommendations and tasks for understanding problem planting sites for specific species. \par \par The list displayed here is used for the planting site type options to choose from in the webform if you collect your field data using a mobile device, as well as in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon. The final list of site types should include all of the classes that exist in your study area (see Notes below). i-Tree Eco includes 7 default planting site types to choose from (see Descriptions below), but you may add or edit site types to customize your project.\par \par \b Steps:\par \b0 1. When you click on the \b Planting Site Type\b0 function, the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par 2. Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of planting site types.\par 3. The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create new classes, delete classes, and undo or redo your most recent actions.\par 4. Manually enter or edit planting site types by entering a brief description in the description column of the table.\par 5. Enter the size associate with each planting site type in the size column.\par \b\par Descriptions:\par \b0\f1\'b7 \f0 Front yard \endash self-explanatory.\par \par \f1\'b7 \f0 Planting strip \endash the narrow strip of grass or planted area that separates a roadway curb or road shoulder from a right-of way line (such as a sidewalk).\par \par \f1\'b7 \f0 Cutout \endash unpaved space within a paved area such as a sidewalk that is designated for planting; also referred to as a treepit or tree well.\par \par \f1\'b7 \f0 Median \endash reserved strip within a roadway that separates lanes of traffic that are moving in opposite directions.\par \par \f1\'b7 O\f0 ther maintained locations \endash sites that are regularly impacted by mowing, weeding, herbicide applications, etc. (e.g., commercial properties, parks).\par \par \f1\'b7 \f0 Other unmaintained locations \endash sites that are not regularly impacted by mowing, weeding, herbicide applications, etc.\par \par \f1\'b7 \f0 Backyard \endash self-explanatory.\par \par \b Notes:\par \b0\f1\'b7 \tab\f0 The planting site types that are displayed here will be available in the webform if you collect your field data using a mobile device, as well as in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon. If you are unsure what site types you will see in the field, we recommend that you keep all of the defaults so they will all be available to choose from.\b\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\par } �

data.name: CarbonSequestrationSpeciesReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Annual Carbon Sequestration of Trees > By Species\b0\par \pard\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides total estimates of gross carbon sequestration of trees by species in your study area. Results are also reported in carbon dioxide equivalent by multiplying carbon sequestration by the ratio of their atomic weights (44/12). This report displays results in table format.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: HydrologyEffectsOfTreesBySpecies
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Hydrology Effects of Trees > By Species\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides total estimates of hydrology effects due to trees. Results are presented by species in your study area. data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Pest Analysis > Pest Review > Of Assessed Trees\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right is an interactive display that allows you to choose which pest you are most interested in and view the tree species that exhibit the signs and symptoms associated with that pest.\par \par \b Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Choose the pest by selecting panel.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}View the tree species sampled in your study area that match the signs or symptoms of the pest you chose in the middle box of the action panel.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}View the tree species sampled in your study area that are \ul not\ulnone a match for the signs or symptoms of the pest you chose but show signs and symptoms of other pests in the box at the bottom of the action panel.\par \pard\par \b Notes\b0 :\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: PollutionRemovalMonthlyReport
data.value:
{tf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{ onttbl{ 0 swiss prq2 charset0 Calibri;}{ 1 nil charset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;ed0\green0 lue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard rdrb rdrs rdrw10 rsp20 \qj\cf1  0 s20\line\pard rdrb rdrs rdrw10 rsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Pollution Removal by Trees and Shrubs > Monthly Removal\par \pard 0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides total monthly and annual estimates of pollution removal and associated value by the trees and shrubs in your study area. This table displays minimum, maximum, and mean pollution removal and value results for the following pollutants:\par \par \pard{\pntext 1'B7	ab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb'B7}} i-360\li720 Nitrogen dioxide (NO\sub 2
osupersub )\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Sulfur dioxide (SO\sub 2
osupersub )\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Ozone (O\sub 3
osupersub )\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Carbon monoxide (CO)\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Particulate matter less than 2.5 microns (PM\sub 2.5
osupersub )\par \pard\par   Notes: 0\par \pard{\pntext 1'B7	ab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb'B7}} i-360\li360 While particulate matter smaller than 10 microns (PM\sub 10
osupersub ) is a significant air pollutant, it is not included in this analysis because i-Tree Eco analyzes particulate matter less than 2.5 microns (PM\sub 2.5
osupersub ), which is a subset of PM\sub 10
osupersub . PM\sub 2.5
osupersub is generally more relevant in discussions concerning air pollution effects on human health.\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard rdrb rdrs rdrw10 rsp20 \qj \par } �

data.name: DiversityIndexReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Diversity Indices > By Strata\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of various diversity indices by strata in your study area. The diversity indices presented here serve as indicators of species richness, dominance, and evenness. This table displays the following information by strata:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\sa200\b Richness \b0\endash number of species sampled.\par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Per area estimates of number of species\b0 \endash density estimates calculated by dividing the total number of species in each stratum by the area of the stratum.\par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Shannon-Wiener diversity index\b0 \endash a diversity index that serves as an indicator for species richness. Because this index assumes that all species within a stratum or study area have been sampled, it has a moderate sensitivity to sample size; therefore, strata and/or cities may not be comparable.\par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Menhinick\rquote s diversity index \b0\endash another diversity index that also serves as an indicator for species richness. This index has a low sensitivity to sample size and therefore may be more appropriate for comparison between strata.\par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Simpson\rquote s diversity index\b0 \endash a diversity index that serves as an indicator for species dominance. It also has a low sensitivity to sample size and therefore may be more appropriate for comparison between strata.\par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Shannon-Wiener evenness index \b0\endash an evenness index that, like the Shannon-Wiener diversity index, assumes that all species within a stratum or study area have been sampled. Similarly, it has a moderate sensitivity to sample size; therefore, strata and/or cities may not be comparable.\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b Sander\rquote s rarefaction technique \b0\endash a technique used for assessing species richness of samples. For a particular stratum, this value is the number of species one would expect to find if four trees were sampled in the stratum. For the city, this value is the number of species one would expect to find if 250 trees were sampled within the city.\par \pard\par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\par } �

data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Reports > Composition and Structure > Population Summary > Percent Tree Cover by Strata\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the percent tree cover in your study area estimated for each year in the future. Results are presented for each stratum in your study area.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\par } �

data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Reports > Charts > Pollution and Weather > Transpiration > By Trees and Shrubs\b0\par \pard\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the hourly transpiration by trees and shrubs. Transpiration is the amount of water moved through plants and released to the atmosphere. This report displays results in line chart and table formats for the user-designated weather year.\par \par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: RunForecast
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Run Forecast\par \pard\b0\par After you have established your settings on this tab, it is time to run the Forecast component of i-Tree Eco and get the results for your project!\par \par Please note that the configuration that is selected in the \b Active Configuration\b0 drop-down list of the ribbon defines the settings for your Forecast results. Make sure that the desired configuration is selected before running Forecast.\par \par Once you click on the \b Run Forecast\b0 button, you will see your \b Configuration Summary\b0 in a pop-up window. Double-check this summary data and click \b Continue \b0 if you are satisfied with the settings displayed here, and Forecast will begin running. Please be patient \endash Forecast runs may take several minutes depending on your defined settings. A progress bar will appear at the bottom of the \b Configuration Summary\b0 window and indicate when the run has completed. You will see that many of the reporting options listed in the ribbon bar are greyed out and unavailable until after the Forecast run is complete.\par \par \b Notes:\b0 \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here. \par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: PestSignSymptomDetailSummarySpeciesReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Pest Analysis > Signs & Symptoms > Summaries by Species\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right displays the percent of trees that exhibit a condition for each tree species sampled (based on signs and symptoms reported following the Pest Detection Module protocol). The table shows a summary of the more detailed results as well as the percent of trees affected by each sign or symptom for each of the tree species sampled.\par \par \b Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 To view your results for all species, choose the \ldblquote All Species\rdblquote option from the drop-down list. \par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}To view your results for each of the tree species individually, use the drop-down list to select the species that you are interested in.\par \pard\par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Reports > Composition and Structure > Leaf Area and Biomass > Leaf Area by Strata\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the total leaf area of the trees in your study area estimated for each year in the future.
