data.name: UtilityConflictForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Project Configuration > Define Data Fields > Maintenance > Utility Conflict\par \pard\par \b0 The \b Utility Conflict\b0 field seen in the action panel to the right identifies the potential or existing conflicts between tree branches and overhead utility lines. During data collection, you can record any utility conflicts for each tree assessed. Determining the maintenance needs of the trees will help with prioritizing, planning, and budgeting for future tree care activities. There are three default utility conflict options (e.g., present and conflicting), but we strongly encourage users to define utility conflicts in a way that is relevant to their project goals.\par \b\par \b0 The list displayed here is used for the utility conflict options to choose from in a mobile data collector, as well as in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon. Your final list of utility conflict options should include all of the types that are relevant to your study area.\par \b\par Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When \b Editing Mode\b0 is \b On\b0 , the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of utility conflict types.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create or delete utility conflict types, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}In the \ldblquote Description\rdblquote column of the table, manually enter or edit utility conflicts.\par \pard\li360\b\par \pard Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the data table here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: IsopreneByShrubs
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Charts > Pollution and Weather > Isoprene > By Shrubs\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right displays hourly estimates of the isoprene emmissions of all shrubs in your study area. This report displayes results in line chart and table formats for the project's weather year.\line\par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par } �

data.name: WildLifeSuitabilityByStrata
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Avian Habitat Suitability > By Strata\par \pard\par \b0 The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of avian habitat suitability for each stratum and your study area as a whole. The suitability index reported here is a unitless value meant to capture the ability of an area to sustain a population based on the habitat features that relate to and influence the patterns of abundance of each species. Two suitability index values are given for each stratum. One value is based on the trees in that stratum and the other value assumes an absence of trees in the stratum.\par \par The index change due to trees is estimated as the following:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 A relative change calculated as the absolute change (see below) divided by the suitability index with trees.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}An absolute change calculated as the suitability index with trees minus the suitability index without trees.\par \pard\par The avian species reported here are based on their ranges so only those species present in the study area will be included in the report. Data is available for up to nine bird species, including American robin, Baltimore oriole, black-capped chickadee, Carolina chickadee, European starling, northern cardinal, red-bellied woodpecker, scarlet tanager, and wood thrush.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: MostImportantTreeSpeciesReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Importance Values > By Species\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of the percent population, percent leaf area, and importance value for each tree species in your study area. Results are ordered from the highest to lowest importance value. Importance value (IV) is calculated as the sum of the percent population and percent leaf area. High importance values do not mean that these trees should necessarily be encouraged in the future; rather these species currently dominate the urban forest structure.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

\pard The table seen in the action panel to the right provides total monthly and annual estimates of pollution removal and associated value by the grass/herbaceous cover in your study area. This table displays minimum, maximum, and mean pollution removal and value results for the following pollutants:\par \par
\pard{\pntext 1'B7	ab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb'B7}} i-360\li720 Nitrogen dioxide (NO\sub 2
osupersub )\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Sulfur dioxide (SO\sub 2
osupersub )\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Ozone (O\sub 3
osupersub )\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Carbon monoxide (CO)\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Particulate matter less than 2.5 microns (PM\sub 2.5
osupersub )\par
\pard\par   Notes: 0\par
\pard{\pntext 1'B7	ab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb'B7}} i-360\li360 These reports are shown only when the location is in 48 US continental states and ground cover information is collected.\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}While particulate matter smaller than 10 microns (PM\sub 10
osupersub ) is a significant air pollutant, it is not included in this analysis because i-Tree Eco analyzes particulate matter less than 2.5 microns (PM\sub 2.5
osupersub ), which is a subset of PM\sub 10
osupersub . PM\sub 2.5
osupersub is generally more relevant in discussions concerning air pollution effects on human health.\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext 1'B7	ab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par

data.name: ReplacementValueReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Replacement Value\par \pard\qj\b0\par The table seen in the action panel on the right displays the trees in your study area by replacement value. Replacement values are estimates of the full cost of replacing trees in their current condition, should they be removed for some reason.\par \par \b Steps:\par \b0 1. Choose if you want to view your report by species, strata/zone, or street by selecting the radio button next to each category.\par 2. Choose the recommended maintenance that you are interested in from the drop-down list.\par \par \b Notes:\par \b0\f1\'b7 \f0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to run the model again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par \f1\'b7 \f0 Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par \f1\'b7 \f0 You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\par } �

data.name: PopSumPublicPrivateStrataReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Population Summary > Public and Private by Strata\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of the number of trees and percent of trees that were designated as being on public or private lands. Public tree and private tree results are summarized in separate tables by strata.\par \par The tables display the following information:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b Number of Trees\b0 \endash number of trees in stratum that were classified as public or private.\par \pard\fi-360\li720\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b % of Strata Trees\b0 \endash percent of trees in stratum that were classified as public or private. For example, in the \ldblquote Summary of Public Trees\rdblquote table, 100% would indicate that all trees located in that stratum were classified as public.\par \pard\fi-360\li720\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b % of Public Trees\b0 \endash percent of all trees classified as public that were located in each stratum. For example, 50% would indicate that half of all public trees were located in that stratum. \par \pard\fi-360\li720\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b % of Private Trees\b0 \endash percent of all trees classified as private that were located in each stratum. For example, 25% would indicate that one quarter of all private trees were located in that stratum. \par \pard\fi-360\li720\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b % of All Trees \b0\endash percent of the total number of trees that were classified as public or private and located in each stratum. For example, in the \ldblquote Summary of Public Trees\rdblquote table, 0% would indicate that none of the total number of trees were classified as public \i and\i0 located in that stratum.\par \pard\fi-360\li720\par \pard\b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: PaperForms
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Data > Data Collection > Paper Form \par \pard\par \b0 i-Tree Eco offers multiple methods for recording the data that you collect in the field. One of these methods is to record your data on paper forms. When you select the \b Paper Form\b0 function, you can view links to the various paper data collection forms in the action panel to the right.\par \par The following types of forms are available:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 For users doing a \b complete inventory\b0 project, there is a single data sheet in xlsx format for recording tree data.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}For users doing a \b plot-based sample\b0 project, there are two data sheets. One in xlsx format for recording tree data and another in doc format for recording plot data.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}For users doing the supplemental \b pest (IPED)\b0 analysis, there is a single data sheet in xlsx format for recording pest observations.\par \pard\b\par \b0 Data sheets are available in xlsx and doc formats to allow for easy customization. Users can save and edit data sheets (e.g., reorder data fields or remove variables that will not be collected) based on the specific data collection needs for their project.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: SusceptibilityPestsStrataReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Pest Analysis > Susceptibility to Pests > By Strata\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right displays results for 36 pests and diseases. Results are reported as the number of trees by strata that are susceptible or not susceptible to each pest. Structural value and leaf area are also estimated based on the number of trees.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 The susceptibility report does not reflect field-collected data about actual risks and harm, but rather calculates the damage that a potential outbreak could have based on species diversity in your population. The number of susceptible trees reflects only the known host tree species in your study area that could experience mortality due to the pest. This susceptibility report will be fully functional even if you choose not to collect the supplemental pest detection data.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: aboutButton
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Support > About\par \pard\par \b0 The \b About\b0 option provides general information for the i-Tree Eco application. data.name: AccuracyOfStrataPreditionsReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Land Use Composition > By Strata\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of the amount of each stratum classified according to the actual land uses measured in the field. i-Tree Eco allows you to stratify your project by different divisions. That is, you can classify which of your plots fall into strata of your choosing (e.g., land use or county). If you have chosen to stratify your project by land use, this table provides a useful look at how closely aligned your strata classifications are with actual land uses.\par \par Strata are defined in the \b Project & Strata Area \b0 function of the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab. Land uses are defined in the \b Land Use\b0 function of the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: DBHsForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Project Configuration > Define Data Fields > DBH\par \pard\par \b0 in the table to the right, DBH categories can be defined. The choosen categories will be available in the mobile data collector and in the the DBH field drop down on the Data > Trees table. In the ribbon bar above use the Delete option to delete rows and the Restore Defaults option to restore the DBH category options.\par \par \b Steps:\par \pard\fi-360\li720\b0 1.\tab When \b Editing Mode\b0 is \b On\b0 , the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par 2.\tab Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of DBH classes.\par 3.\tab The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create new classes, delete classes, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par 4.\tab In the "ID" column, enter a unique number to identify the DBH category.\par 5.\tab In the "Description" column, enter a description for the DBH category. This description will be shown during data collection and displayed in the drop down field on the Data > Trees table.\par 6.\tab In the "DBH" column, enter the DBH value that will be assigned to the DBH category. This value will be used in any calucation that requires a discrete DBH value.\b\par \pard\par Notes:\par \pard\fi-360\li720\b0\f1\'b7\tab\f0 Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the data table here to a comma separated values (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\b\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\par } �

data.name: CarbonSequestrationStrataReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Annual Carbon Sequestration of Trees > By Strata\b0\par \pard\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides total estimates of gross carbon sequestration of trees by strata in your study area. Results are also reported in carbon dioxide equivalent by multiplying carbon sequestration by the ratio of their atomic weights (44/12). This report displays results in bar chart and table formats.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: rtProject
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs20\par To get started, go to the \b File\b0 menu and select one of the following options:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b New Project\b0 \endash to create a new Eco project.\par \b{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Open Project \b0\endash to open an existing Eco project.\par \b{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Open Example Project \b0\endash to open and explore an example project provided by Eco. \par \pard\par \pard\sl240\slmult1 Choose from the available tabs at the top of the ribbon bar to access the different phases of an Eco project. Within each tab, you can click on one of the functions or buttons in the ribbon above. The feature that you choose will become available in the action panel to the right.\par \lang9\f1\fs22\par } �

data.name: NetAnnualBenefitsInventoriedTreesReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Measured Tree Details > Benefits and Costs > Net Annual Benefits for Inventoried Trees\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right reports the economic value of the environmental benefits provided by all of the sampled trees in your study area. The user-defined management costs are reported so net benefits and benefit-cost ratio can be estimated for all sampled trees. From the total benefits and costs reported, per tree estimates are also presented in this table.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: tpProjectOptions_plot
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Riched20 10.0.17763}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par
\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Project Configuration > Project Definition > Data Collection Options\par
\pard\b0\par The \b Data Collection Options\b0 tab seen in the action panel to the right is where you identify what data you will collect in the field. \par \par \b Steps:\b0\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360 Choose whether you will be collecting your data in metric (e.g., centimeters) or English (e.g., inches) units by clicking next to your preference.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Check the box next to each data variable that you will be collecting. See Notes below.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Define custom variables by providing a name in the box at the bottom of the action panel (e.g., Invasive (y/n)). You may add up to three custom variables. Data fields cannot be open-ended, and must be divisible into 10 or fewer categories.\par
\pard\par Go through the other tabs, \b Project Settings \b0 and \b Location\b0 , which are available in the \b Project Definition\b0 function. When you are satisfied with the project settings that you have entered, click \b OK\b0 in the top right-hand corner of the action panel. This will save the edits that you have made. Click \b Cancel\b0 if you do not wish to save your edits.\par \par \b *IMPORTANT*\par \b0 i-Tree Eco requires users to collect two plot measurements and two tree measurements. While this approach allows users with limited, existing inventories to run the model, it also has substantial limitations. The accuracy of ecosystem service estimates can be improved significantly by providing more optional tree measurements. The information below describes minimum and highly recommended fields available for i-Tree Eco data collection.\par \par \b Data & Ecosystem Service Relationships\b0 \par The letters in parentheses after each description below indicate the ecosystem service or model function affected by the data. Each of these components, excluding energy effect and avian habitat suitability, will be calculated using estimated or default data variables if the highly recommended fields are not collected. Energy effect (E) and avian habitat suitability (H) are optional model components that require additional data and are described in more detail below.\par \par A = air pollution removal; C.Stor = carbon storage; C.Seq. = carbon sequestration; E = energy effect; F = Forecast, R = avoided runoff; S = structural or compensatory value; V = volatile organic compound emissions; U = ultraviolet index effect; H = avian habitat suitability\par \par \b Minimum Required Plot Measurements\b0 \i \i0\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\sa200\b Percent measured \b0\endash amount of the plot that can be accessed, measured, and/or included in this study. This allows for data collection for a partial plot. For example, if 10% of the plot is obscured from view behind a building or a tall stockade fence on land that you could not get permission to access, you would record 90%. Safety concerns may also be a factor in accessing portions of the plot.\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b Percent tree cover\b0 \endash amount of the plot covered by tree canopy. This data is also reported for the entire study area. (A, E, R, U, H)\par
\pard\par \b Minimum Required Tree Measurements\b0 \i \i0\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\sa200\b Species \b0\endash\b \b0 species common name, scientific name, or code. Eco features species data (e.g., growth rates) for over 7,000 tree and shrub species. Refer to support resources for options on adding new species to future Eco database. (A, C.Stor., C.Seq., E, F, R, S, V)\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b DBH \b0\endash\b \b0 diameter at breast height (in/cm) available for up to six stems. The height of the DBH measurement, typically 4.5 feet or 1.37 meters above the ground, is required and used for quality assurance checks or for re-measuring trees in future assessments. Users can choose to input DBH as either measured (discrete values) or categorized. If measured is chosen, no further action is required. If categorized is chosen, users can then choose to customize DBH categories after clicking OK in the top right of this window by navigating to Define Data Fields, DBH in the Project Configuration tab. Once OK is clicked, this option cannot be changed. (C.Stor., C.Seq., F, S, H)\par
\pard\li720\par
\pard\b Recommended Tree Measurements \b0 \par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\sa200\b Land use \b0\endash\b \b0 describes how the land is being used where a tree is growing. The entry adjusts model biomass and decomposition rates and affects compensatory value estimates. The 13 default land use categories are customizable. These land use classes are not used to stratify project results. (C.Seq., S, H)\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}\b Total tree height \b0\endash a single data entry describing the total tree height from the ground to the top (alive or dead) of the tree. (A, C.Stor., C.Seq., E, F, R, V, H)\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}\b Crown size \b0\endash\b \b0 requires five data entries, including two measurements of crown width (north to south and east to west), two measurements of crown height (height to live top and height to crown base), and an estimated percent of crown missing volume adjustment, which accounts for areas void of leaves and branches. (A, E, R, V)\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}\b Crown health \b0\endash a single data entry that users can choose to record as \b Dieback\b0 or \b Condition\b0 . Crown health is based on a visual assessment of the amount of dead branches in the crown. If recording \b Dieback\b0 , users will collect the percent of the crown that is composed of dead branches. If recording \b Condition\b0 , users will enter the inverse of percent dieback (i.e., 100 \endash percent dieback). (C.Seq., E, F, S, H)\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b Crown light exposure \b0\endash a single data entry indicating the number of sides of tree canopy that receive direct sunlight. This measurement accounts for crown competition and adjusts growth rates. (CStor., C.Seq., F)\par
\pard\par \b Optional Model Components\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Energy\b0 estimates are available for sample and inventory projects in the U.S., Canada, Australia, the U.K., and select countries in Europe. As seen in the descriptions above, energy effect estimates use species and total tree height measurements. We strongly recommend collecting the height variable to improve the quality of your energy effect estimates. In addition, the energy option requires two data entries which the model uses to orient a tree in relationship to an acceptable building.\par
\pard\li720\b\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li1080 Distance to building \b0\endash the distance from a tree to the closest point of a space-conditioned dwelling. (E)\par
\pard\li360\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li1080\b Direction to building \b0\endash a compass measurement from the tree to the nearest point of the building. This directional variable orients the tree\rquote s relationship to a structure for energy modeling. (E)\par
\pard\par
\pard\li720 Up to four buildings can be designated to have energy effect relationships with a single tree. Refer to the Eco Field Guide for further discussion on acceptable building types and tree parameters for energy effect modeling. \par
\pard\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b Avian Habitat Suitability\b0 estimates are only available for sample projects in the U.S. As seen in the descriptions above, avian habitat suitability is estimated based on percent tree cover, tree diameter (DBH), land use, total tree height, and crown health. Though land use, total tree height, and crown health are not required variables, collecting these data will greatly improve avian habitat suitability estimates. Two additional variables, \b percent shrub cover\b0 and \b ground cover\b0 , are also used in the avian habitat suitability model component. Without collecting these data, wildlife estimates cannot be provided.\par
\pard\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b User Tree ID \b0 data field allows users to input a unique identifier for individual trees. Eco automatically assigns an ID number for each tree in a project as ordered integers. Although these identification numbers can be changed manually, they cannot be changed during the inventory data import process. Therefore, the User ID field can be used to incorporate tree identifiers applicable to specific inventories.\par
\pard\par \b Notes:\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b0 Some data variables include drop-down menus to further define how you will collect your data. If you are collecting \b Street tree/non-street tree\b0 or \b Public/private\b0 tree details, you can choose a default for all trees from the drop-down menu.\par
\pard\li360\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Some data variables require you to collect additional variables. By checking the box for one variable, the box for the additional variable will automatically be checked. These variables are defined by a note in parentheses below the variable. If you choose to collect either plot \b Land use \b0 or tree \b Land use\b0 , you will be required to collect the other. If you choose to collect \b Shrub details\b0 , you will be required to collect \b Percent shrub cover\b0 . However, you may choose to collect \b Percent shrub cover\b0 without being required to collect \b Shrub details\b0 .\par
\pard\par } �

data.name: videoLearningButton
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue255;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \f1 Support > Video Learning\par \pard\b0\par The webpage seen in the action panel to the right provides an access point where you can get instructional videos and archived webinars to learn more about the i-Tree Eco application.\par \par Also available at:\par {\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "https://www.itreetools.org/resources/videos.php"}}{\fldrslt{\ul\cf1 https://www.itreetools.org/resources/videos.php}}}\f1\fs20\par \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\par } �

data.name: tpProjectOptions_full
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fmodern\fprq1\fcharset0 Courier New;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Riched20 10.0.17763}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par
\pard Project Configuration > Project Definition > Data Collection Options\par \b0\par The \b Data Collection Options\b0 tab seen in the action panel to the right is where you identify what data you will collect in the field. \par \par \b Steps:\b0\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360 Choose whether you will be collecting your data in metric (e.g., centimeters) or English (e.g., inches) units by clicking next to your preference.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Check the box next to each data variable that you will be collecting. See Notes below.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Define custom variables by providing a name in the box at the bottom of the action panel (e.g., Invasive (y/n)). You may add up to three custom variables. Data fields cannot be open-ended, and must be divisible into 10 or fewer categories.\par
\pard\par Go through the other tabs, \b Project Settings \b0 and \b Location\b0 , which are available in the \b Project Definition\b0 function. When you are satisfied with the project settings that you have entered, click \b OK\b0 in the top right-hand corner of the action panel. This will save the edits that you have made. Click \b Cancel\b0 if you do not wish to save your edits.\par \par \b *IMPORTANT*\par \b0 i-Tree Eco requires users to collect two tree measurements. While this approach allows users with limited, existing inventories to run the model, it also has substantial limitations. The accuracy of ecosystem service estimates can be improved significantly by providing more optional tree measurements. The information below describes minimum and highly recommended fields available for i-Tree Eco data collection.\par \par \b Data & Ecosystem Service Relationships\b0 \par The letters in parentheses after each description below indicate the ecosystem service or model function affected by the data. Each of these components, excluding energy effect, will be calculated using estimated or default data variables if the highly recommended fields are not collected. Energy effect (E) is an extra model component that requires additional data and is described in more detail below.\par \par A = air pollution removal; C.Stor = carbon storage; C.Seq. = carbon sequestration; E = energy effect; F = Forecast, R = avoided runoff; S = structural or compensatory value; V = volatile organic compound emissions; U = ultraviolet index effect\par \par \b Minimum Required Tree Measurements\b0 \i \i0\par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\sa200\b Species \b0\endash\b \b0 species common name, scientific name, or code. Eco features species data (e.g., growth rates) for over 7,000 tree and shrub species. Refer to support resources for options on adding new species to future Eco database. (A, C.Stor., C.Seq., E, F, R, S, V)\par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b DBH \b0\endash\b \b0 diameter at breast height (in/cm) available for up to six stems. The height of the DBH measurement, typically 4.5 feet or 1.37 meters above the ground, is required and used for quality assurance checks or for re-measuring trees in future assessments. Users can choose to input DBH as either measured (discrete values) or categorized. If measured is chosen, no further action is required. If categorized is chosen, users can then choose to customize DBH categories after clicking OK in the top right of this window by navigating to Define Data Fields, DBH in the Project Configuration tab. Once OK is clicked, this option cannot be changed. (C.Stor., C.Seq., F, S)\par
\pard\li720\par
\pard\b Recommended Tree Measurements \b0 \par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\sa200\b Land use \b0\endash\b \b0 describes how the land is being used where a tree is growing. The entry adjusts model biomass and decomposition rates and affects compensatory value estimates. The 13 default land use categories are customizable. These land use classes are not used to stratify project results. (C.Seq., S)\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}\b Total tree height \b0\endash a single data entry describing the total tree height from the ground to the top (alive or dead) of the tree. (A, C.Stor., C.Seq., E, F, R, V)\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}\b Crown size \b0\endash\b \b0 requires five data entries, including two measurements of crown width (north to south and east to west), two measurements of crown height (height to live top and height to crown base), and an estimated percent of crown missing volume adjustment, which accounts for areas void of leaves and branches. (A, E, R, V)\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}\b Crown health \b0\endash a single data entry that users can choose to record as \b Dieback\b0 or \b Condition\b0 . Crown health is based on a visual assessment of the amount of dead branches in the crown. If recording \b Dieback\b0 , users will collect the percent of the crown that is composed of dead branches. If recording \b Condition\b0 , users will enter the inverse of percent dieback (i.e., 100 \endash percent dieback). (C.Seq., E, F, S)\par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b Crown light exposure \b0\endash a single data entry indicating the number of sides of tree canopy that receive direct sunlight. This measurement accounts for crown competition and adjusts growth rates. (CStor., C.Seq., F)\par
\pard\par \b Optional Model Components\par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Energy\b0 estimates are available for sample and inventory projects in the U.S., Canada, Australia, the U.K., and select countries in Europe. As seen in the descriptions above, energy effect estimates use species and total tree height measurements. We strongly recommend collecting the height variable to improve the quality of your energy effect estimates. In addition, the energy option requires two data entries which the model uses to orient a tree in relationship to an acceptable building.\par
\pard\f1\par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li1080\b\f0 Distance to building \b0\endash the distance from a tree to the closest point of a space-conditioned dwelling. (E)\par
\pard\li360\par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li1080\b Direction to building \b0\endash a compass measurement from the tree to the nearest point of the building. This directional variable orients the tree\rquote s relationship to a structure for energy modeling. (E)\par
\pard\par
\pard\li720 Up to four buildings can be designated to have energy effect relationships with a single tree. Refer to the Eco Field Guide for further discussion on acceptable building types and tree parameters for energy effect modeling. \par \par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b User Tree ID \b0 data field allows users to input a unique identifier for individual trees. Eco automatically assigns an ID number for each tree in a project as ordered integers. Although these identification numbers can be changed manually, they cannot be changed during the inventory data import process. Therefore, the User ID field can be used to incorporate tree identifiers applicable to specific inventories.\par
\pard\b\par Notes:\par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 Some data variables include drop-down menus to further define how you will collect your data. If you are collecting \b Street tree/non-street tree\b0 or \b Public/private\b0 tree details, you can choose a default for all trees from the drop-down menu.\par
\pard\par } �

data.name: PestSignSymptomDetailSummaryStrataReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Pest Analysis > Signs & Symptoms > Summaries by Strata\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right displays the percent of trees that exhibit a condition for each stratum (based on signs and symptoms reported following the Pest Detection Module protocol). The table shows a summary of the more detailed results as well as the percent of trees affected by each sign or symptom for each stratum.\par \par \b Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 To view your results for all strata, choose the \ldblquote All Strata\rdblquote option from the drop-down list. \par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}To view your results for each of the strata individually, use the drop-down list to select the strata that you are interested in.\par \pard\par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ForecastByStrataBasalAreaReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Reports > Composition and Structure > Population Summary > Basal Area by Strata\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the total basal area of the trees in your study area estimated for each year in the future. The total basal area in Year 0 is based on the current basal area in your study area from the structural estimates provided by Eco. Results are presented for each stratum in your study area.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ForecastPestForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Forecast > Custom Options > Extreme Events > Pest Outbreaks\par \pard\b0\par The \b Pest Outbreaks \b0 function seen in the action panel to the right can be used to customize your Forecast results at a more advanced level. One of the advantages of defining one or more extreme events, such as a pest outbreak, is that you can model what your urban forest will look like in the future as a result of the loss of trees. You can choose to include a single pest outbreak or multiple ones. \par \par Please note that making changes here is optional. If you do not want to include pest outbreak scenarios in your projected results, do not make changes in this action panel (see Notes below). There are no pest outbreak scenarios included by default.\par \par If you decide you would like to pursue the pest outbreaks option, you must define all of the following variables:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\sa200\b Pest species \b0\endash the pest or disease that causes the outbreak.\par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Outbreak occurs in year \b0\endash the year in which the pest outbreak occurs.\par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Lasts how many years \b0\endash the duration of the pest outbreak. For example, if you set the pest outbreak to begin in Year 5 and last a duration of two years, then your extreme event will end in Year 7.\par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Resulting annual mortality (%) \b0\endash the annual mortality rate that will occur as a result of the pest outbreak scenario. The rate that you provide indicates the percent of trees that will die as a result of the event. Default mortality rates for each pest were derived from the National Insect and Disease Forest Risk Assessment report (2012).\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b Plant host trees during event? \b0\endash determines what types of species will be included in a tree planting scenario. This option is relevant to you if you have defined a pest event \ul and\ulnone have included tree planting scenarios in the \b Trees to Plant \b0 function. Certain tree species are known to be hosts to harmful pests and diseases. If you select this option, known host trees will be included in the species composition of trees planted.\par \pard\par \b Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Choose the pest species from the drop-down list (see Notes below).\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Set the year in which the pest outbreak occurs by either typing the year directly in the box provided or using the up and down arrows on your keyboard to increase or decrease the number.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}In the box to the right, define the duration of your event.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Set the annual mortality rate that occurs as a result of your pest outbreak by either typing the year directly in the box provided or using the up and down arrows to increase or decrease the number.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Indicate whether or not you will be planting host trees during the event.\par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}To delete the pest outbreak scenario that you defined, click on the \b Clear\b0 button.\par {\pntext\f0 7.\tab}Once you have defined a pest outbreak scenario that you are satisfied with, click the \b Add\b0 button.\par {\pntext\f0 8.\tab}Your pest outbreak scenario will appear in the table at the bottom of the action panel.\par {\pntext\f0 9.\tab}You may choose to include multiple pest outbreak scenarios.\par {\pntext\f0 10.\tab}Use the toolbar located above the upper left-hand corner of the table to undo, redo, or delete a pest outbreak scenario in the table.\par \pard\par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 Pest outbreak scenarios added here assume that the species composition of lost trees as a result of the event will be even across all known host species.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}When defining pest species, common name is listed in the drop-down list with scientific name in parentheses.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}The Forecast component of i-Tree Eco estimates the future structure and function of your urban forest by incorporating anticipated growth and mortality rates. This provides you with an estimate of what your urban forest will look like in the future. You can even include future tree planting scenarios or possible adverse events, such as a storm or pest infestation, to predict their impact on your urban forest.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: AvoidedRunoffIndReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Individual Level Results > Tree Benefits and Costs > Hydrology Effects\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides total estimates of the stormwater runoff avoided due to each tree sampled in your study area. This table includes estimates for the following:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Species\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Leaf area\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Potential evapotranspiration\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Evaporation\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Transpiration\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Water intercepted\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Avoided runoff\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Avoided runoff value\par \pard\par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: RetrieveResults
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset0 Times New Roman;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Reports > Track & Retrieve Results\par \pard\b0\par After you have established your project settings in the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab and entered your field data in the \b Data\b0 tab, it is time to send your data to the server and retrieve the results for your project!\par \par When you click on the \b Submit Data for Processing\b0 button, your project settings and field data will be sent to the i-Tree server where the Eco model will be run. When your data have been processed, you will be notified by email that the results are ready to download. If you do not receive your results within 24 hours, please contact info@itreetools.org. \par \par Your results can be retrieved from the i-Tree server by using the \b Track &\b0 \b Retrieve Results\b0\f1\fs24 \f0\fs20 function. This function can also be used to check the status of your data submission.\b\par \b0\par \b Steps:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360 In the \b Retrieve Processed Results \b0 window, click \b OK\b0 .\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Please be patient while results are downloaded.\par \pard\par If you are unsure whether or not you have run the Eco model, you can check the \b Project Metadata\b0 report on this tab. This information is especially useful since you may find it necessary to send your data to the server more than once throughout the duration of your project (see Notes below). \par \par \b Notes:\b0 \par \pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and retrieve your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: EnergyEffectsReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Energy Effects > Of Trees\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides total estimates of the effect of trees in your study area on energy usage. This table includes estimates for the following energy effects:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Effect on building energy use (i.e., increases or decreases in the number of MBTUs and MWHs used for heating or cooling residential buildings in study area)\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Effect on carbon emissions (i.e., increases or decreases in carbon emissions from power sources as a result of changes in energy use)\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Value of effects (i.e., values associated with the changes in building energy use and carbon emissions)\par \pard\par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Negative values in the table indicate an \ul increase\ulnone in building energy use, carbon emissions, or values due to trees. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: GroundCoversDataForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Data > Inventory Data > Ground Covers\par \pard\b0\par The \b Ground Covers\b0 table seen in the action panel to the right displays the ground cover data for plots that you collected in the field (see Notes below). This is where you will enter your ground cover data manually or edit your previously added or imported data. While working in this table, you may use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to help manually enter new data or edit data that has already been added.\par \par \pard\tx720\b Steps to Manually Add/Edit Data:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Click in the box where you would like to enter data and begin typing.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the Tab key on your keyboard or the left and right arrows to move from side to side within a record.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the up and down arrows on the keyboard to move from top to bottom between records.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}For boxes that contain drop-down lists, you can choose your data from the list or begin typing and the matching label will be automatically filled in.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}The table can be sorted by column in ascending or descending order. To sort, click on the desired column header.\par \pard\par \pard\tx720\b Steps for Using Actions Tools:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When you click on the \b Trees\b0 function, the \b Actions\b0 group will become available in the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the \b New \b0 tool to create a new record in the shrub table.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Use the \b Undo\b0 and \b Redo\b0 tools to correct your most recent actions (e.g., creating, editing, or deleting a record).\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Use the \b Delete\b0 tool to remove the selected record(s) from the table.\par \pard\par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you have imported your data from the mobile data collector using the \b Retrieve from Mobile \b0 function of the \b Data\b0 tab, you will see all of the imported field data for your project here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you opened a project or are working with data that was previously entered, you will see all of the field data for your project here.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Some data fields are defined on the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab. If you do not see the options you want from the drop-down list for a certain data field, you will need to go back to the \b Project Configuration\b0 tab to edit the list of options for that data field.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the shrub data here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \fi-360\li360\qj\b\par } �

data.name: AllergyIndexOfTreesByStrataumReport
ForecastByStrataLeafBiomassReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Reports > Composition and Structure > Leaf Area and Biomass > Leaf Biomass by Strata\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the total leaf biomass of the trees in your study area estimated for each year in the future. The total leaf biomass in Year 0 is based on the current leaf biomass in your study area from the structural estimates provided by Eco. Results are presented for each stratum in your study area.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration tab or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.value:

\pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides a summary of Eco\rquote s benefit estimates, including replacement value, energy savings, carbon storage and sequestration, avoided runoff, and pollution removal, for each of the trees sampled in your study area.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par
