data.name: ITreeMethodsForm
EnableEditing_Data
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Riched20 10.0.10586}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Data > Editing Mode \par
\pard\par \b0 The field data that you enter in the \b Data\b0 tab is an important input for your i-Tree Eco project. The \b Editing Mode\b0 function helps to prevent unintentional changes to the data you have entered.\par
\pard\tx720\par
\pard After you send data and retrieve results on the \b Reports\b0 tab, the \b Editing Mode \b0 function will become available on the \b Data\b0 tab (i.e., it will no longer be greyed out and the function will read \ldblquote Editing Mode: Off\rdblquote ). This indicates that the tab is in View-only mode so each function may be viewed, but not edited.\par \par However, the data that you enter in this tab may be edited with caution. In order to do this, you will need to switch to Editing mode by clicking on the \b Editing Mode \b0 function once it has become available. After clicking on it, the function will be greyed out and read \ldblquote Editing Mode: On.\rdblquote Edits may be made at that time. Please note that if you edit your data, the results in the \b Reports\b0 tab may not reflect the changes that you made. To ensure that they do, send your data to the server and load your results again.\par \par } �

data.name: ForecastTotalLeafBiomassReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp40 Forecast > Reports > Composition and Structure > Leaf Area and Biomass > Leaf Biomass\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the total leaf biomass of the trees in your study area estimated for each year in the future. The total leaf biomass in Year 0 is based on the current leaf biomass in your study area from the structural estimates provided by Eco.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration tab or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: AnnualCostsForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Data > Inventory Value > Annual Costs\par \pard\par \b0 The \b Annual Costs\b0 field seen in the action panel to the right identifies the costs associated with your project. The costs entered here and the urban forest benefits estimated by Eco are used to calculate the benefit-cost ratio of those benefits, which can be a valuable public-policy tool. If you are interested in comparing the benefits and costs of your urban forest, you will need to gather annual cost data for your study area (see Notes below).\par \par There are no default costs for this field because they can vary significantly from place to place. The values that you provide here are primarily the annual costs associated with the management of your urban forest, such as tree planting or removal. However, there may be less obvious tree-related costs to consider, such as sidewalk repair costs or litigation fees.\par \par Already submitted your project to the Eco server and retrieved your results? No problem \endash this form can be edited at any time and you will not be required to submit your project again. Results on the \b Reports\b0 tab will reflect the change in annual costs immediately.\par \par \b Steps:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360 For previously entered annual costs, use the save function to keep a record of those values. This record is useful in the event that you want to use those annual costs again in the future.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Manually enter the annual costs that you would like the model to use in the boxes (see Notes below).\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}When you are satisfied with the annual costs you have set, click \b OK\b0 in the top right-hand corner of the action panel. This will save the edits that you have made to the costs.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Total costs will be summed automatically in the \ldblquote Total $\rdblquote column and \ldblquote Total Costs $\rdblquote row.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Click \b Cancel\b0 if you decide to revert to all of the previous costs, whether 0 values or those that you had previously entered manually. \par \pard\b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 Because benefits are reported as annual sums, citywide costs associated with tree management should also be annual values.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Some communities wish to separate out costs for public versus private trees. This allows the benefit-cost ratio to be calculated separately \endash for instance, for trees in the right-of-way whose maintenance is paid for by the adjacent property owner versus trees in the right-of-way that are maintained using public funds. If you will distinguish between public and private trees in your inventory, complete the column for private costs to estimate costs associated with private trees.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the annual costs here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: MaintenanceRecommendedForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Project Configuration > Define Data Fields > Maintenance > Maintenance Recommended\par \pard\par \b0 The \b Maintenance Recommended\b0 field seen in the action panel to the right identifies various types of recommended maintenance. During data collection, you can record the type of maintenance recommended for each tree assessed. Determining the maintenance needs of the trees will help with prioritizing, planning, and budgeting for future tree care activities. There are six default types of maintenance recommendations (e.g., small tree routine), but we strongly encourage users to define maintenance recommendations that are relevant to their project goals.\par \par The list displayed here is used for the recommended maintenance options to choose from in a mobile data collector, as well as in the \b Data \b0 tab of the ribbon. Your final list of recommended options should include all of the types of maintenance that are relevant to your study area. \par \par \b Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When \b Editing Mode\b0 is \b On\b0 , the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of recommended maintenance types.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create or delete maintenance types, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}In the \ldblquote Description\rdblquote column of the table, manually enter or edit recommended maintenance types.\par \pard\par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 Use the \b CSV \b0 function in the ribbon to export the data table here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: TranspirationShrubReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10 Reports > Charts > Pollution and Weather > Transpiration > By Shrubs\b0\par \pard\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the hourly transpiration by shrubs. Transpiration is the amount of water moved through plants and released to the atmosphere. This report displays results in line chart and table formats for the user-designated weather year.\par \par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ForecastEventForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Forecast > Custom Options > Extreme Events > Weather Events\par \pard\b0\par The \b Weather Events \b0 function seen in the action panel to the right can be used to customize your Forecast results at a more advanced level. One of the advantages of defining one or more extreme events, such as a severe storm, is that you can model what your urban forest will look like in the future as a result of the loss of trees. You can choose to include a single weather event or multiple ones. \par \par Please note that making changes here is \ul optional\ulnone . If you do not want to include weather event scenarios in your projected results, do not make changes in this action panel (see Notes below). There are no weather event scenarios included by default.\par \par If you decide you would like to pursue the weather events option, you must define all of the following variables:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\sa200\b Weather type \b0\endash the type of weather event.\par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Weather occurs in year \b0\endash the year in which the weather event occurs.\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b Resulting mortality rate (%)\b0 \endash the mortality rate that will occur as a result of the weather event scenario. The rate that you provide indicates the percent of trees that will die as a result of the event. Default mortality rates provided for each weather event were derived from various sources describing the impact of past weather events.\par \pard\par \b Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Choose the weather type from the drop-down list.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Set the year in which the weather event occurs by either typing the year directly in the box provided or using the up and down arrows on your keyboard to increase or decrease the number.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Set the annual mortality rate that occurs as a result of your weather event by either typing the year directly in the box provided or using the up and down arrows to increase or decrease the number.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}To delete the weather event scenario that you defined, click on the \b Clear\b0 button.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Once you have defined a weather event scenario that you are satisfied with, click the \b Add\b0 button.\par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}Your weather event scenario will appear in the table at the bottom of the action panel.\par {\pntext\f0 7.\tab}You may choose to include multiple weather event scenarios.\par {\pntext\f0 8.\tab}Use the toolbar located above the upper left-hand corner of the table to undo, redo, or delete a weather event scenario in the table.\par \pard\par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 Weather event scenarios added here assume that the species composition of lost trees as a result of the event matches the species composition of the current urban forest.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}The Forecast component of i-Tree Eco estimates the future structure and function of your urban forest by incorporating anticipated growth and mortality rates. This provides you with an estimate of what your urban forest will look like in the future. You can even include future tree planting scenarios or possible adverse events, such as a storm or pest infestation, to predict the impact on your urban forest.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: AirQualityHealthImpactsAndValues
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Air Quality Health Impacts and Values\par
\pard\b0\par The \b Air Quality Health Impacts and Values \b0 report seen in the action panel to the right is a summary report that provides estimates of the number of adverse health incidents that were avoided due to changes in pollutant concentration levels. The estimates in the table reflect the population of your study area. The dollar values reflect the economic value of those reductions in health incidents.\par \par The same health effects are not analyzed for each pollutant. Blank values indicate that incidence reduction and value are not estimated for that pollutant and health effect. For example, acute bronchitis is only estimated for particulate matter less than 2.5 microns (PM\sub 2.5\nosupersub ).\par \par \b Notes:\b0 \par
\pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par
\pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\f1\fs22\lang9\par } �

data.name: SidewalkTotalsLookupReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Composition and Structure > Maintenance > Sidewalk Conflicts by Species\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides estimates of the number of trees, percent of species, and percent of all trees that were designated as posing a sidewalk conflict. Results are presented by type of sidewalk conflict and species.\par \par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: LocationSitesForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Project Configuration > Define Data Fields > Location Site\par \pard\par \b0 The location site field seen in the action panel on the right is a category that identifies the location of the planting site relative to nearby buildings. During data collection, you would record the location site of each tree that you collect data for. Although these location sites will not be reported, they can be helpful when looking through your records in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon.\par \par The list displayed here is used for the location site options to choose from in the mobile data collector if you collect your field data using a mobile device, as well as in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon. The final list of location sites should include all of the classes that exist in your study area (see Notes below). \par \par \b Steps:\par \pard\fi-360\li720\b0 1.\tab When you click on the \b Location Site\b0 function, the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par 2.\tab Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of location sites.\par 3.\tab The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create new classes, delete classes, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par 4.\tab Manually enter or edit location sites by entering a brief description in the description column of the table.\par \pard\li360\tx360\par \pard\b Notes:\par \pard\fi-360\li360\b0\f1\'b7\tab\f0 The location sites that are displayed here will be available in the mobile data collector if you collect your field data using a mobile device, as well as in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon. If you are unsure what location sites you will see in the field, we recommend that you keep all of the defaults so they will all be available to choose from.\b\par \b0\f1\'b7\tab\f0 Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the data table here to a comma separated values (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\b\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\par } �

data.name: PollutantRemovalMonthlybyGrassChart
data.value:
{tf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0
ouicompat\deflang1033{ onttbl{ 0 swiss prq2 charset0 Calibri;}{ 1 nil charset0 Calibri;}{ 2 nil charset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard rdrb rdrs rdrw10 rsp20   0 s20\par Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Pollution Removal by Grass/Herbaceous > Monthly Removal (chart display)\par
\pard 0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides total monthly estimates of pollution removal and associated value by the grass/herbaceous cover in your study area. This report displays charts and tables for the following pollutants:\par \par
\pard{\pntext 2'B7	ab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb'B7}} i-360\li720 Nitrogen dioxide (NO\sub 2
osupersub )\par {\pntext 2'B7	ab}Sulfur dioxide (SO\sub 2
osupersub )\par {\pntext 2'B7	ab}Ozone (O\sub 3
osupersub )\par {\pntext 2'B7	ab}Carbon monoxide (CO)\par {\pntext 2'B7	ab}Particulate matter less than 2.5 microns (PM\sub 2.5
osupersub )\par
\pard\par Several of the charts and tables in this report present pollution removal and the associated value for all of the pollutants studied. The remaining charts show pollution removal and value for the pollutants individually.\par \par   Notes:\par
\pard{\pntext 2'B7	ab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb'B7}} i-360\li360 0 The reports for grass/herbaceous cover will be available only when the location is in 48 US continental states and ground cover information is collected. \par {\pntext 2'B7	ab} 0 While particulate matter smaller than 10 microns (PM\sub 10
osupersub ) is a significant air pollutant, it is not included in this analysis because i-Tree Eco analyzes particulate matter less than 2.5 microns (PM\sub 2.5
osupersub ), which is a subset of PM\sub 10
osupersub . PM\sub 2.5
osupersub is generally more relevant in discussions concerning air pollution effects on human health.\par {\pntext 2'B7	ab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext 2'B7	ab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext 2'B7	ab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par
\pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1 1 s22\lang9\par } �

data.name: PotentialEvapotranspirationShrubReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10 \b\f0\fs20\par Reports > Charts > Pollution and Weather > Potential Evapotranspiration > By Shrubs\b0\par \pard\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the hourly potential evapotranspiration by shrubs. Potential evapotranspiration is the sum of the evaporation from the soil and the transpiration from plants that would occur if an unlimited amount of water were available. This report displays results in line chart and table formats for the user-designated weather year.\par \par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ForecastBenefitsCarbonSequestrationStrataReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Reports > Benefits > Carbon Storage and Sequestration > Carbon Sequestration by Strata\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the total amount of carbon sequestered by the trees in your study area estimated for each year in the future. Results are presented for each stratum in your study area.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: PollutantConcentrationPPMReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par Reports > Charts > Pollution and Weather > Air Pollutant Concentration (ppm)\par \pard\qj\b0\par The report seen in the action panel on the right displays the hourly pollution concentration in parts per million based on air quality data. This report displays results in line chart and table formats for the user-designated pollution year.\par \par \b Notes:\par \b0\f1\'b7 \f0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to run the model again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par \f1\'b7 \f0 Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ForecastReplantingForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;\red0\green0\blue255;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Forecast > Custom Options > Trees to Plant\par \pard\b0\par The \b Trees to Plant\b0 function seen in the action panel to the right can be used to customize your Forecast results at a more advanced level. One of the advantages of defining tree planting scenarios is that you can model what your urban forest will look like in the future as a result of one or more tree planting events. You can choose to include a single tree planting event or include multiple plantings to simulate an annual tree planting program. \par \par Please note that making changes here is \ul optional\ulnone . If you do not want to include tree planting scenarios in your projected results, do not make changes in this action panel (see Notes below). There are no tree planting scenarios included by default.\par \par If you decide you would like to pursue the tree planting option, you must define all of the following variables:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\sa200\b Applies to stratum \b0\endash The stratum that you chose to subdivide your study area by. For each tree planting scenario, you may choose to plant trees in either a single stratum or all strata.\par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Set DBH of new trees to \b0\endash The DBH (diameter at breast height) of the tree stem measured at 4.5 feet (1.37 meters) above the ground. This defines the diameter of all of the planted trees for a scenario.\par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Trees to plant annually \b0\endash The number of trees that will be planted annually in your planting scenario.\par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Start planting in year \b0\endash The time period of your tree planting. You may choose what year your planting scenario will begin. \par \b{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}For how many years? \b0\endash The length of your tree planting period in years. For example, if you set tree planting to begin in Year 5 and last the duration of 30 years, then your planting scenario will end in Year 35.\par \pard\b Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Choose the stratum where tree planting will occur by selecting a stratum from the drop-down list.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Set the DBH of the new trees for planting by either typing the size directly in the box provided or using the up and down arrows on your keyboard to increase or decrease the number (see Notes below).\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Set the number of trees to plant annually by either typing the number directly in the box provided or using the up and down arrows to increase or decrease the number.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Set the time period for tree planting by defining the start year and total number of years. To define a year, either type the year directly in the box provided or use the up and down arrows to increase or decrease the number.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}To delete the tree planting scenario that you defined, click on the \b Clear\b0 button.\par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}Once you have defined a tree planting scenario that you are satisfied with, click the \b Add \b0 button.\par {\pntext\f0 7.\tab}Your tree planting scenario will appear in the table at the bottom of the action panel.\par {\pntext\f0 8.\tab}You may choose to include multiple tree planting scenarios.\par {\pntext\f0 9.\tab}Use the toolbar located above the upper left-hand corner of the table to undo, redo, or delete a tree planting scenario in the table.\par \pard\par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 Tree planting scenarios added here assume that the species composition of planted trees matches the species composition of the current urban forest.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Units are shown to the right of the \b Set DBH of new trees\b0 \b to\b0 box. Please make note of these units and be sure that the DBH you enter corresponds to the units listed.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}The Forecast component of i-Tree Eco estimates the future structure and function of your urban forest by incorporating anticipated growth and mortality rates. This provides you with an estimate of what your urban forest will look like in the future. You can even include future tree planting scenarios or possible adverse events, such as a storm or pest infestation, to predict their impact on your urban forest.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Natural ingrowth or regeneration of the urban forest is not accounted for in Forecast modeling. One way to incorporate natural regeneration into your future estimates would be to factor it in here as if it were a tree planting program. For more information on natural regeneration, please read the following paper: {\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "http://www.nrs.fs.fed.us/pubs/jrnl/2012/nrs_2012_Nowak_003.pdf"}}{\fldrslt{\ul\cf2 http://www.nrs.fs.fed.us/pubs/jrnl/2012/nrs_2012_Nowak_003.pdf}}}\f0\fs20 \par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: OxygenProductionStrataAreaReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Benefits and Costs > Oxygen Production of Trees > By Strata per Unit Area\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right provides per area (density) estimates of oxygen production of trees by strata in your study area. Per area estimates are calculated by dividing the total oxygen production in each stratum by the area of the stratum. This report displays results in bar chart and table formats.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you have not stratified your project, results will be presented for a single stratum.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\par } �

data.name: ForecastByStrataTreeCoverAreaReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Forecast > Reports > Composition and Structure > Population Summary > Tree Cover Area by Strata\par \pard\b0\par The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the tree cover area in your study area estimated for each year in the future. The tree cover area in Year 0 is based on the current tree cover in your study area from the structural estimates provided by Eco. Results are presented for each stratum in your study area.\par \b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 If you make changes to the Forecast settings for this configuration or re-run your i-Tree Eco project on the \b Reports\b0 tab, you will need to run Forecast again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports here. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: GroundCoversForm
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset2 Symbol;}{\f2\fswiss\fprq2 Calibri;}{\f3\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f4\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Riched20 10.0.17763}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\line Project Configuration > Define Data Fields > Ground Cover\par
\pard\par \b0 The \b Ground Cover\b0 field seen in the action panel to the right describes the materials covering the ground of the sample plots that are estimated during data collection. When doing a plot-based sample, you can record the percentages (must total 100%) of the area covered by the various materials. There are 11 default ground cover classes (see Descriptions below). Users may choose to keep all or some of the default classes or provide their own.\par \b\par Steps to Customize:\par
\pard {\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When \b Editing Mode\b0 is \b On\b0 , the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of ground cover classes.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create or delete classes, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}In the \ldblquote ID\rdblquote column, enter your ground cover code. The ID must be a unique number.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}In the \ldblquote Description\rdblquote column, enter your ground cover class. This can be in number or text format.\par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}In the \ldblquote Category\rdblquote\b \b0 column, choose one of the 11 default ground cover classes that corresponds to the custom class. \par {\pntext\f0 7.\tab}To make text changes, click in the desired box on the table.\par
\pard\par \b Descriptions:\par
\pard{\pntext\f4\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf4\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 Building\f1 \f0\endash includes buildings with green roofs.\par
\pard\par
\pard\li360 *IMPORTANT*\par Percent building cover in energy and avian habitat modeling. Users interested in those analyses should either keep the default building class or include a custom class that is mapped to the default building class.\par
\pard\par
\pard{\pntext\f4\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf4\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Cement \par
\pard\par
\pard{\pntext\f4\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf4\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Tar \endash blacktop/asphalt.\par
\pard\par
\pard{\pntext\f4\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf4\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Rock \endash pervious rock surfaces such as gravel, brick, or flagstone walkways or patios (without mortar), as well as sand in playgrounds or added as topping to existing soil. (Note: Large solid rock outcrops should be categorized as other impervious.)\par
\pard\par
\pard{\pntext\f4\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf4\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Bare soil \endash includes naturally occurring sand.\par
\pard\par
\pard{\pntext\f4\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf4\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Duff/mulch \endash loose organic material, leaf litter.\par
\pard\par
\pard{\pntext\f4\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf4\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Herbs \endash herbaceous ground cover, other than grass, including agricultural crops. \par
\pard\par
\pard{\pntext\f4\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf4\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Grass\par
\pard\par
\pard\li360 *IMPORTANT*\par Percent maintained grass cover is used in avian habitat modeling. Users interested in that analysis should either keep the default grass class or include a custom class that is mapped to the default grass class.\par
\pard\par
\pard{\pntext\f4\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf4\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Unmaintained grass\par
\pard\par
\pard\li360\f2 *IMPORTANT*\par Grass, unmaintained grass, and herbs factor in to pollution modeling for U.S. projects. Pollution results will be affected by how these ground covers are categorized in the field or if new fields are mapped to these ground cover designations.\f0\par
\pard\par
\pard{\pntext\f4\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf4\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Water \endash natural water bodies and rivers, excluding temporary standing water.\par
\pard\par
\pard{\pntext\f4\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf4\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Other impervious \f2\endash impervious surfaces, other than buildings, cement, and tar, including large solid rock outcrops, swimming pools, man-hole covers, utility boxes, headstones, artificial turf, etc. (Note: Artificial turf should be categorized as rock if the underlying material is pervious.)\f0\par
\pard\b\par Notes:\par
\pard{\pntext\f4\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf4\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 The classes that are displayed here will be available on a mobile data collector, as well as in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon. \par {\pntext\f4\'B7\tab}Use the \b CSV \b0 function in the ribbon to export the data table here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par
\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par
\pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b0\f3\fs22\lang9\par } �

data.name: DefinePlotsManuallyForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset2 Symbol;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Project Configuration > Define Plots > User Defined\par \pard\par \b0 If you are conducting a plot-based sample, you need to define the plots where you will be collecting your data. The \b User Defined\b0 function seen in the action panel to the right is one of the methods for defining your plots. This option allows you to create a sample of plots manually in i-Tree Eco (see Notes below).\par \par \b Steps:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360 When you click on the \b User Defined\b0 function, the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of strata.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create or delete strata, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Enter the size of your sample plots in the box provided above the table. \par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Enter the number of plots to be added to each stratum in the column labeled \ldblquote Plots To Add.\rdblquote\par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}When you are satisfied with your strata and zones, click \b OK\b0 in the top right-hand corner of the action panel. This will save the edits that you have made to the table.\par {\pntext\f0 7.\tab}Click \b Cancel\b0 if you decide to revert to all of the previous values, whether default values or those that you had previously entered manually.\par \pard\par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 The units (i.e., acres or hectares) shown next to the plot size box are determined by the units specified in the \b Project Definition\b0 function. Make note of these units and be sure that the plot size you enter corresponds to the units listed.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}The standard plot size for i-Tree Eco projects is 0.1 acres (0.04 hectares).\par \pard\fi-360\li360\f1\'b7\tab\f0 The \ldblquote Strata Description,\rdblquote \ldblquote Strata Abbreviation,\rdblquote and \ldblquote Area\rdblquote\b \b0 fields are informed by the \b Project &\b0 \b Strata Area\b0 function on this tab. If you make changes in this function or in the \b Project & Strata Area\b0 function, the changes will be reflected in both functions. Additionally, plot samples defined using the \b Load from File \b0 or \b via Google Maps \b0 functions will be reported here.\par \pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 The \ldblquote Strata Description\rdblquote that you enter is used in reporting some Eco results by strata on the \b Reports \b0 tab. \par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}The size entered in the \ldblquote Area\rdblquote column is used to calculate the per unit area, or density, estimates that are included in some of the Eco results on the \b Reports\b0 tab. This area should represent the total area of the strata. The more accurate the area entered here, the better your density estimates will be.\par {\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}The \ldblquote # of Plots\rdblquote column is automatically filled in based on the plots already defined during plot sample creation.\par \pard\par For more information on stratifying your study area, please see the \b User Manual \b0 or\b \b0 user guide to \b Pre-stratified Samples\b0 ,\b Post-stratified Samples\b0 , or \b Unstratified Samples \b0 (depending on your project goals) available under \b User Guides \b0 in the \b Support\b0 tab.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: ConditionsForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Project Configuration > Define Data Fields > Crown Health\par \pard\par \b0 The \b Condition \b0 field seen in the action panel to the right describes tree crown health as estimated during data collection. Crown health is based on a visual assessment of the amount of dead branches (i.e., dieback) in the crown. To record condition, users will enter the inverse of percent dieback (i.e., 100 \endash percent dieback). i-Tree Eco includes 22 default condition classes. \par \par Users may choose to record crown health as dieback instead of condition. To change how you would like to record crown health, go to \b Project Definition\b0 > \b Data Collection Options\b0 .\par \par \b *IMPORTANT*\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 We highly recommend that users creating a new Eco project use the default condition classes. Working with the default classes fosters more precise data collection in the field and standardization in reporting. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}For users importing tree data from a spreadsheet, customizing these classes will be necessary if the tree data does not follow the default classes.\par \pard\par \b Steps to Customize:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When \b Editing Mode\b0 is \b On\b0 , the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of condition classes.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create or delete classes, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}In the \ldblquote Description\rdblquote column, enter your condition class. This can be in number, range, or text format.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}In the \ldblquote % Condition\rdblquote\b \b0 column, enter the percent that corresponds to the condition class. For example, the defaults provided include a 90%-95% (good) condition class for which the midpoint of that range, 93, is entered in \ldblquote % Condition.\rdblquote \par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}To make text changes, click in the desired box on the table.\par \pard\b\par Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 The classes that are displayed here will be available on a mobile data collector, as well as in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the data table here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: InventorySummaryStrataReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Individual Level Results > Composition and Structure > Of Trees By Strata\par \pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right presents a summary of the data collected in the field as well as additional estimated tree characteristics for each of the trees sampled in your study area. This table includes estimates for the following characteristics:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720 Tree count\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Canopy cover\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Leaf area\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Leaf biomass\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Basal area\par \pard\par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: PlotComments
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\cf1\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Individual Level Results > Miscellaneous > Plot Comments\par \pard\b0\par For plots that comments were collected, the table in the action panel to the right provides Plot ID, Stratum, Address, data collection Date, Crew, indicates if data collection was completed or not, and the collected Comments.\line\par \b Notes:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b0 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par } �

data.name: StructuralValueIndReport
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Riched20 10.0.19041}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \cf1\b\f0\fs20\line\cf0 Reports > Formatted Reports > Measured Tree Details > Benefits and Costs > Replacement Value\par
\pard\b0\par The table seen in the action panel to the right provides total estimates of the replacement value of each tree sampled in your study area. Results also include estimated standard error and the percent contribution of each tree to the total replacement value of all sampled trees.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par
\pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par
\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: UVIndexReport
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue255;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Report > Charts > Pollution and Weather > Raw and Source Data > UV Index\par \pard\par \b0 The report seen in the action panel to the right displays the daily ultraviolet (UV) index in your study area. UV radiation is emitted by the sun and while beneficial to humans in small doses, can have negative health effects when people are overexposed. The UV index scale was developed by the World Health Organization to more easily communicate daily levels of UV radiation and alert people to when protection from overexposure is needed most. UV index values are estimated from UV radiation and adjusted based on local elevation and cloud cover.\par \par This report displays results in line chart and table formats. UV data is from the same year as the user-designated weather and pollution year. It is presented as a daily value at solar noon when the sun is highest in the sky.\par \par \b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 For more information on the UV index scale, visit {\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "http://www.who.int/uv/intersunprogramme/activities/uv_index/en/"}}{\fldrslt{\ul\cf1 http://www.who.int/uv/intersunprogramme/activities/uv_index/en/}}}\f0\fs20\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}If you make changes to your project settings or add or edit your field data, you will need to send your data to the server and load your results again to ensure that your changes are reflected in your reports. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the toolbar at the top of the action panel to zoom in and out and save or print the report you have open.\par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}You can change how units (English or metric) and species names (common or scientific) are displayed in your reports by clicking on the appropriate button in the ribbon above.\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\par } �

data.name: rtData
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs20\par To get started, go to the \b File\b0 menu and select one of the following options:\par \par \pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li720\b New Project\b0 \endash to create a new Eco project.\par \b{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Open Project \b0\endash to open an existing Eco project.\par \b{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}Open Example Project \b0\endash to open and explore an example project provided by Eco. \par \pard\par \pard\sl240\slmult1 Choose from the available tabs at the top of the ribbon bar to access the different phases of an Eco project. Within each tab, you can click on one of the functions or buttons in the ribbon above. The feature that you choose will become available in the action panel to the right.\par \lang9\f1\fs22\par } �

Within each tab, you can click on one of the functions or buttons in the ribbon above. The feature that you choose will become available in the action panel to the right.\par \par } �

data.name: LandUsesForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \qj\b\f0\fs20\par \pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 Project Configuration > Define Data Fields > Land Use\par \pard\par \b0 The \b Land Use\b0 field seen in the action panel to the right describes the overall land use that is seen during field data collection. These are not the classes that are used to stratify project results. There are 14 default land use classes (see Descriptions below). Users may choose to keep all or some of the default classes or provide their own. However, the land use variable is used to adjust model biomass, decomposition rates, and compensatory value estimates so all custom land use classes must be mapped to an Eco default class. \par \b\par Steps to Customize:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 When \b Editing Mode\b0 is \b On\b0 , the \b Actions\b0 group will become available on the ribbon.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Use the tools in the \b Actions\b0 group to customize the table of land use classes.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}The \b Actions\b0 tools allow you to create or delete classes, undo or redo your most recent actions, and restore defaults.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}In the \ldblquote Code\rdblquote column, enter your land use code. This can be a number or letter, but may only be 1 character.\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}In the \ldblquote Description\rdblquote column, enter your land use class. This can be in number or text format.\par {\pntext\f0 6.\tab}In the \ldblquote Category\rdblquote\b \b0 column, choose one of the 13 default land use classes that corresponds to the custom class. \par {\pntext\f0 7.\tab}To make text changes, click in the desired box on the table.\par \pard\b\par Descriptions:\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\b0 Agriculture \endash cropland, pasture, orchards, vineyards, nurseries, farmsteads and related buildings, feed lots, rangeland, and timberland/plantations that show evidence of management activity for a specific crop or tree production.\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlcont\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\li360\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Cemetery \endash includes any small unmaintained areas within cemetery grounds.\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlcont\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\li720\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Commercial/industrial \endash land being used for commercial activities, including retail, services, and professional business. Also includes standard industrial land uses, such as manufacturing or processing, and outdoor storage/staging areas as well as parking lots in downtown areas that are not connected with an institutional or residential use.\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlcont\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Golf course \endash includes entire grounds, whether maintained or not.\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlcont\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Institutional \endash schools, hospitals/medical complexes, colleges, religious buildings, government buildings, etc.\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlcont\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Multi-family residential \endash structures containing more than four residential units.\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlcont\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Park \endash includes parks in undeveloped (unmaintained) areas as well as developed areas. (Note: Trees or plots in forested stands are best categorized as being on the Forest land use.)\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlcont\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Residential \endash freestanding structures serving one to four families.\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlcont\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Transportation \endash includes limited access roadways and related greenspaces (such as interstate highways with on and off ramps, sometimes fenced), as well as railroad stations, tracks and yards, shipyards, airports, etc. (Note: If plot falls on any other type of road, or associated median strip, classify according to nearest adjacent land use.)\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlcont\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Utility \endash includes power-generating facilities, sewage treatment facilities, covered and uncovered reservoirs, and empty stormwater runoff retention areas, flood control channels, and conduction.\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlcont\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Vacant \endash includes land with no clear intended use. (Note: Abandoned buildings and vacant structures should be classified based on their original intended use.)\par \pard\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Water/wetland \endash streams, rivers, lakes, and other water bodies, natural or constructed. (Note: Small swimming pools and fountains should be classified based on the adjacent land use.)\par \pard\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 Other \endash land uses that do not fall into one of the categories listed. (Note: This designation should be used sparingly as it provides little useful information for the model.)\par \pard\fi-360\li360\par \pard\b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf1\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 The classes that are displayed here will be available on a mobile data collector, as well as in the \b Data\b0 tab of the ribbon. \par {\pntext\f1\'B7\tab}Use the \b CSV\b0 function in the ribbon to export the data table here to a \ldblquote comma separated values\rdblquote (csv) file. Data exported as a csv file are compatible with Microsoft Excel and text editors such as WordPad and Notepad.\par \pard\par } �

data.name: MobileSubmitSampleForm
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset2 Symbol;}} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.21.2510;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\brdrb\brdrs\brdrw10\brsp20 \b\f0\fs20\par Data > Data Collection > Submit to Mobile\par \pard\par \b0 i-Tree Eco offers multiple methods for recording the data that you collect in the field. One of these methods is to record your data using the mobile data collector. You can access the mobile data collector from any web-enabled mobile device, such as a smartphone or tablet, and import your collected data into i-Tree Eco from the web (also available on \b Data\b0 tab of ribbon). The Eco mobile device functionality is not an app that you have to download from a store; it is a web-based inventory data collection form. \par \par The purpose of the \b Submit to Mobile\b0 function seen in the action panel to the right is to send your project configuration to the server where you will be able to access it using a mobile device and the i-Tree Eco mobile data collector (see Notes below).\par \par \b *IMPORTANT*\par \b0 Before you can start working with the mobile data collector on your mobile device, you must submit your project configuration here (see Notes below). \i If you do not submit your project configuration, you will not be able to access the mobile data collector from your mobile device.\i0\par \par \b Steps:\par \pard{\pntext\f0 1.\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlbody\pnf0\pnindent0\pnstart1\pndec{\pntxta.}} \fi-360\li360\b0 Enter and confirm your email address in the space provided on the right-hand side of the action panel.\par {\pntext\f0 2.\tab}Enter and confirm your password in the space provided on the right-hand side of the action panel.\par {\pntext\f0 3.\tab}Select all of the records that you want submitted to the mobile data collector.\par {\pntext\f0 4.\tab}Click \b Submit Project\b0 .\par {\pntext\f0 5.\tab}Check the email account that you provided for instructions on accessing the i-Tree Eco mobile data collector for your project.\par \pard\li360\par \pard\b Notes:\b0\par \pard{\pntext\f2\'B7\tab}{\*\pn\pnlvlblt\pnf2\pnindent0{\pntxtb\'B7}}\fi-360\li360 i-Tree Eco allows you to submit your project multiple times. This gives you the ability to change or tweak your project settings and then make the new version available on the mobile data collector.\par \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\lang9\f1\fs22\par } �
